item.title: One week left until I leave for Peru
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Starting last fall, I attended an information session about One Laptop per Child and the internships they offer that span the globe. OLPC is the original creating of the netbook, dubbed the 100$ laptop by the media. Although the laptop does not cost this, rather around 190$, they did spark a revolution in cheap, mobile computing. They redesigned the laptop to work to teach children, to give them the tools to learn and make their situation better. As an EECS engineering student, this sounded like a great opportunity to spend time in another country doing some ecotourism. I applied as soon as the application was ready and was accepted soon after. Its now only a week away from my departure :) My intern duties are described as "technical". This means that I will be traveling to different schools fixing laptops, setting laptops up, and aiding in the integration of the laptops with the everyday workings of the school. I will arrive in Lima and spend a week training. Then I will travel to the Ancash region with my two other fellow interns. We will be based in Huaraz and travel to different schools in the region. Most language spoken will be in Spanish :P Learn more about the XO (the laptops name) and OLPC at their website. View some photos of south america. [mappress]

item.title: One Day Left
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
As of now there is less than 24 hours until I am on a plane on my way to Peru. If you are wondering, am I excited?, duh! Anyways this post won't be long just giving a quick run-down of my setup and the things that I am taking. When considering that I am going to be gone for about four months, I had to really consider the best way to keep things light. I decided that I wanted to be able to carry everything with me at one time, so that moving around would be manageable. To this end I decided on the following set-up:
  • One large backpack - 70L Osprey Aether: This is the main bag that holds the majority of things like my clothes, sleeping bag, camping equipment, etc.
  • One small backpack - ~20L Camelback with 3L bladder: This will be an everyday backpack I can take with me when sightseeing or doing day trips.
  • One messenger bag - Performance bike messenger bag: This is my main bag for carrying things like my computers and camera.
The smartest thing that I did was to use lot of smaller bags and stuff sacks within the other bags. This helps to compartmentalize things and keep things organized. I've put all computer things in a bag, socks in a bag, camping and cook equipment in a bag. The idea is that I want to be able to get to things quickly and keep them from getting disorganized. item.title: Flying to Peru
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: This morning I got up (Sep 3) at 3am for the drive to LAX for my 920am flight. I think this is the first time I can say that my parents dogs were woken up by me instead of the other way around. My flight was two legs, the first one from LAX to Houston and the second from Houston to Lima. The best part about this was that my connections were at the same gate so I didn't have to go anywhere. Each flight was packed, but it didn't hinder the flight experience. I worked on the XO laptop most of the time, playing with the programs and building a game with one of them (the brick smashing one). The flights went really quick it seemed and I have to commend the folks at Continental for being awesome. They were really professional and everything went down without a hitch. I gladly recommend them to anybody else. Once I arrived in Lima it was the customary long wait in customs for the guy to spend 20 seconds just giving me stamps. Seriously, no questions, nothing, just STAMP, STAMP, buenos noches! I think I wowed him with my "Hola" upon approaching the counter that he knew I could be trusted. After this got in the cab the hostel sent, whereupon the driver began to speak extremely quick spanish, then wait patiently while I bumbled through a response. I had as much a hard time speaking spanish because I was holding on for dear life as the driver weaved his way in and out of traffic like a go-cart driver. I don't know how we didn't crash as we were careening down the street at mach-10, blinkers flashing, horn honking, and talking at the same time. Skillz! [mappress]

item.title: Day 1 - Lima: Exploring Miraflores
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Wow, so first day in Lima. I spent most the day in Miraflores exploring the area. I woke up around 9am due to not having gone to sleep until around 2am. I slowly roused myself to shave, take a shower, and eat some complimentary breakfast rolls. At which point, I promptly packed my backpack with a guide book, a spanglish dictionary, some snacks, cameras and off I went (approximately 1030-11am).
Left the Hostel and made my way down to the beach area. Really I was up on the cliffs overlooking the beach, but close enough. I walked along the cliff edge through a nice park, into another park called Lover's Park (see picture of massive statues making out) and on down into the trendy shopping center called Larco Mar. It's an awesome shopping mall built into the cliff side overlooking the ocean. There were a lot of people walking dogs and riding bikes along the cliff edge through the park. My favorite was the extremely decked out mountain bikers riding at about 5mph, I mean, what's the point if you aren't going fast and down a mountain? At this point I turned and walked up Larco Ave into the main Miraflores area. I found a supermarket to get some lunch, which consisted of about a liter of drinkable fruit yogurt (YUM) and a couple empenadas (meat filled pastry, again YUM). I ate and continued my way up into the downtown parks.
At this point I decided to go and visit Huaca Pucllana, a massive mud brick pyramid in the middle of the city. Pretty interesting, there was a Peruvian hairless dog there. One of the ugliest creatures I've yet to see, but also interesting. His skin felt like oily cloth, very friendly too. On the tour I met a young Canadian lady (I really want to use the word chick, but I'm being PC, so YCL it is), who was also traveling alone for the day. We decided to pool our funds and take a taxi to a really nice museum. Spent a couple hours at the museum looking at old Peruvian artifacts, including the erotic room, and returned back to Miraflores to a sports bar to watch the Peru-Canada soccer game. Consequently this was also the best place to be to watch college football as well because it was packed with Americans. We ended up not watching most of the soccer game, but talking to a really helpful and friendly guy who gave us great tips on places to stay, where to go, and how to get there (Thanks!). So I watched some college football highlights (haha Ole Miss) and drank a Peruvian beer (YUM). After the game ended, Canada surrendered 0-2, uh I mean, lost, me and YCL walked to her tour bus where she left to take a night tour of downtown Lima. I noticed a large grouping of people across in the park and went to investigate. Consequently, it was a large group of strangers dancing, awesome! So I sat watching the people dance (you can too, see the video) and was talked to by two random guys for about an hour then a different guy after that. The second guy was super friendly, a network engineer for a phone company in Peru, and we went on getting some food and talking for another hour or so. I tried Inca Kola, Amos would love it because it tastes like Cotton Candy and bubble gum, don't think I'll get it again :/. After this, my brain having turned to mush from trying to not sound like a 1st grader speaking spanish all day, I returned to my hostel to promptly collapse. item.title: Day 2 - Lima Centro
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Well today was interesting. I met my other two interns Josh and Hope, who I'll be spending the next couple months with. They arrived in the morning after a long red-eye flight and promptly went to sleep. Around noon Josh and myself, Hope deciding to sleep, took a cab into Lima Centro and went to see the sights downtown. We saw a couple plazas that had some parades/processions going on there. Then we visited the Inquisition Museum (museum de inquiscion) and the San Francisco church. Both were interesting, but the most interesting thing had to be the crypts in the church. They were full of bones of people who had been buried there. After the church, Josh and I made our way up into Chinatown and through the market. It was a good opportunity to talk with and get to know Josh. After this we caught a Taxi back to our Hostel and headed out to find dinner. We had Arabic food, which wasn't too bad. Food here is quite cheap. You can get a meal for about 10 soles or about 3.50$.
For dinner we had a surfer guy join us from the hostel who has spent the better part of his adult life working as a tree planter in canada during the summer (he's from canada, eh?) and then surfing in south america during the winter. He has lots of interesting stories, of course. After dinner we returned to the hostel for some darts, foosball (which I dominated in, YEAH!), and a game of bananagrams (like scrabble). I won both of those games too (YEAH!). Then we went to have a late night snack and are now exhausted!

item.title: Day 3 - Getting ready for the "Ministry"
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was pretty easy going. We woke up kind of late and spent the early part of the morning going over our XO's and material that we will need to know for tomorrow's training at the ministry. We went for a late lunch at a Backpacker kitchen for a fixed meal (price of 10$). I got the ceviche for the appetizer and "cau cau" for the main dish. For those of you who don't know, like I didn't, "cau cau" is actually cows stomach. It wasn't too bad, but I don't think that I'll be getting it again :). We had a pear syrupy compote for desert, it wasn't too bad. The best part of the meal was actually when I accidentally ate a tomato looking pepper, who soon induced a 5 minute coughing fit and tear session as my sinuses experienced a serious butt whopping.
After this I spent a majority of the day fixing my website, the theme got corrupted so I switched to a new one, you like? Josh and Hope (hereon to be described as Hosh), went to Huaca Pullcana which I had already visited. After their return we got dinner and relaxed. We are calling it an early night because tomorrow we have to go to the ministry for training, starting at 830 (meaning an early rise time for the 40 minute cab ride). We're excited to begin the work and are anxious to see what will happen tomorrow.
Sorry, but I don't have any cool pictures today :( but should have some more soon! [mappress]

item.title: Day 4 - "Tell us why you wanted to do this program..."
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today was an early riser for us. We were up at 640ish to get ready for our big training day at the ministry, I even shaved. We got ready and hopped in a cab to make our way to the Biblioteca Nacional (National Library). We were able to experience the Lima morning traffic rush, which wasn't that bad actually. Upon arriving at the Ministry, we promptly went to the front of the line to ask for "Carlos", our babysitter for the day. Those in the line promptly gave us death stares and cursed us under their breath for not standing in line. Although their victory was soon had as we were told Carlos wasn't there, so we'd have to wait (smiles from the line). So we waited for Carlos to show up, which he did, then we got to really cut the line, HA! Carlos is a nice, opera loving (and blogging) gentleman, that was the only person to speak with us in English the entire day. He showed us in, bought us coffee, and did a quick introduction. Here began the interesting part... We were introduced to Marie Antoinette, who of course only speaks rapid spanish in a vocabulary I've yet to even think of mastering, and Carlos asks us to all introduce ourselves, talk about our school, where were from, what we studied, and WHY WE WANTED TO DO THIS PROGRAM. Of course, IN SPANISH, for the benefit of Marie. Hope went first, sounded great with her spanish, and wowed them. Next I was to speak. I bumbled through a explanation, with Marie finishing and correcting words. Then, because Carlos had to step out of the room for a phone call, he returns, and asks us to repeat. So I stumble around like a 1st grader, againnnn, Marie corrects almost everything, againnnn, and Carlos nods and smiles at my imbecile attempt to sound knowledgeable about myself. Josh follows behind and does pretty good, although still incurs the correcting wrath of Marie! For the rest of the day, we spend time learning how to motivate the teachers to use laptops. Negotiate with them! Apparently the kids learn great on them and master the technology quickly, but the teachers are difficult to convince. We were taught how to repair the software of the laptop, the most issues simply require flashing the laptop. We had a spectacularly large lunch of chicken and french fries, with an Inca Kola (bubble gum soda) to wash it down. I promise myself at Lunch to go for a run later. Once we finished we returned back to the hostel, to make bus reservations for our trip to Huaraz (on Thursday morning) and try to find a place to stay (almost got that). Then I went for my run, and felt like I wanted to toss my cookies the whole time. Afterwards, we got some food, I didn't puke, of the Chifa (chinese) variety that tasted just like Panda Express. After my chinese experiences in San Francisco, I probably won't go back :P Esta todo para ahora, Buenas Noches! [mappress]

item.title: Day 5 - Dia de los nuevos amigos
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
For our last day in Lima, Hosh (Josh and Hope) and myself decided to venture back to Lima centro for a nice afternoon of exploring. We decided to try our luck with the bus system so that we could save some money (only 33 cents to ride) and also to experience how the locals travel. Needless to say the buses drive about as crazy as the taxi drivers, just with more mass. The other interesting part about their bus systems is street vendors can come on the bus to try and sell some snacks.
Once we go to our destination, we found they were having a food festival. However, they were charging a ticket fee (which you had to stand in line for a long time) or of course you could scalp some tickets for a slightly greater fee. A Limeno (person from Lima) from Queens New York talked to us for a bit and tried to help us get tickets so that we didnât get taken advantage of. He said that Hopeâs Spanish (which is essentially fluent) wasnât very good, which really pissed her off to Josh and mine amusement. However, once we learned that they were also charging for food inside, we abandoned this attempt. (First Friend of the Day)
After our failed attempt at the food festival, we started walking and ended up in a mall. It was fairly similar to malls in the states. We ate at the food court where Josh and I tried the local fast food chain Bembos. I got a hamburger with some sort of egg hash on it, the burger tasted more like sausage though. It wasnât too bad, but I think I will try something else next time :-P. After our snack we made our way through Lima Centro, where we met another Limeno (Second Friend of the Day) who wanted to take us to his local bar. We were in the process of sharing a beer, when we were assaulted by an extremely drunk man. (Third Friend of the Day) He tried to sell us some things, we declined, so of course then he asked for a bit of beer. At this point, I would have told him to get lost, but our host gave him a bit, so the guy sat down and proceeded to talk with us (read, spit). He sat down between me and our Limeno friend, while Hosh were on the other side of the table. Let me say that this guy was extremely drunk and dirty, I was extremely uncomfortable! Hosh seemed to find my discomfort funny, needless to say I was not laughing. He continued to linger for too long of a time, talking to us about the random thoughts he has. Eventually we got the bar owner to get rid of the guy. We finished up our beers and began to say our goodbyes to our Limeno friend. At this point (and I feared this might happen), he mentions he has three kids, only works a couple of days, etc, and wonders if we could give him some money to buy them dinner. We offer to buy them some food, but of course that wonât do. So we give him nothing and say goodbye.
At this point we begin to make our way towards Parque de la Reserva (park) to see a light show. We met up with a couple friends of Hopeâs (Fourth and Fifth friends of the Day), both doing Fulbright scholarships in Peru. We got a quick bite to eat, I had a nice pie and a hot chocolate, then we returned to the park and watched the light show. It was quite impressive (see the attached videos). Afterwards, we said goodbyes and got on a small bus back to our Hostel. Let me say that there are a couple types of buses in Lima, and Peru in general, those that are public and those that are private ones. The private ones, combis, are like big vans. They speed from corner to corner, with a guy hanging out of the door yelling sing-song the destination. They push you into the van and speed along. Our door dude (for lack of a better term), knew people along the way. He jumped out and grabbed a friendâs cigarette, puffed it and got back in, Josh and I were floored. We made it back to our Hostel in one piece with a few good stories from our day. We packed up our things to prepare our things for the trip to Huaraz the next morning. What a day of new friends!
More pics will be added. [nggallery id=13]

item.title: Day 6 - Nine Hours in a Bus from Lima to Huaraz
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today, I got my first taste of south american land transport. Quite an experience, although not for the reasons you might think. We woke up early to take a taxi to the bus station. We got to the bus station around 9 (for our 930 departure), got our tickets and then went to wait at the departing terminal (I say this because the station was like a mini-airplane terminal). At which point the gate we were standing at was taken over by a TV commercial crew. Would this cause our gate to be moved? Of course, but not for another 20 minutes :/. Anyways, we got on the bus no problem and headed on our way (25 minutes late).
We got second level seats in the front of the bus. This was great for two reasons: the view and its as far as possible from the terrible smelling bathroom. However, as we came to find out the bathroom smell would pale in comparison to the other passengers riding with us. We were traveling almost exclusively with a large group of Israelis. Now, don't misunderstand me, I am Jewish and harbor no ill feelings towards Jewish people, but these people were just plain rude! It was quite embarrassing. They had one person in their whole group that could speak English (for about 20 of them). The others consistently insisted (I use this term lightly because it was really more like yelling) that the stewardess (bus stewardess?) speak English too them. The poor stewardess. They were also quite pushy and disrespectful of others boundaries. The guy sleeping with me felt it was ok to just slouch over into my seat for a lot of the ride (see pic), until I started talking to him. Then we became more friendly and he knocked it off. He was traveling with a couple friends around south america for about 6 months (had only just arrived). Although when I asked if he spoke english, he responded with a huffy "Of course!". He also tried to instruct me on how to eat my mango, which I already knew how. Just a little pretentious :P
Beyond that, the bus ride went smoothly, I did some reading, wrote a blog post, watched some movies, and nearly puked when we were going through the pass. I got some serious vertigo and for about 45 minutes was working on my prana breathing (yoga people, is that the right term?). Huaraz is at 10,000ft and needless to say, I have had a small headache since I got here. The area outside of Lima, was pretty much a desert wasteland, not even cactus grows there. The cliffs on the coast were amazingly breathtaking. Josh got some pictures, but I wasn't able to. After this the desert becomes more lush, but even in Huaraz it is a dry place. The last bit of the bus ride was super sketchy though, as the road was very dark with lots of potholes. Speeding through the dark, dodging potholes like a go-cart driver, in a double-decker bus is enough to give anyone a start! We arrived fine though, got our bags, got to the hotel, and ate some food. I tried Guinea Pig, or Cuy, a specialty in the area from a French restaurant (also got veggies, thank god). Cuy was quite delicious, I'll definitely try it in other places. After that we returned back to our hotel where we all promptly passed out!

item.title: Day 7 - Huaraz, a quaint mountain town
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was our first full day in Huaraz (pronounced waaraz), and it was really interesting. Read more about the city here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huaraz This is a very nice high-altitude town full of lots of markets and sun! No really, it was about 80degrees today. The entirety of the town center can be walked around and the outskirts only take about 10 mins to reach by foot. We are staying in a nice hotel close to the Plaza de Armas (city center). We can walk to get cheap food all over.
We had a meeting with the Specialist this morning. We reviewed our jobs and what we will be doing. Hosh will be spending two weeks at a time in a village, living with the teachers. I will be staying in Huaraz and each day traveling to the villages, until about Oct 4 when I too will begin to stay out in the villages. The reason we are staying in the villages is because they are too far away to bus to and from in one day. For this first week, I'll be getting up at 5am on Mon and Tues to leave with the teachers. Wed is a field day, where I can play soccer with the kids, or whatever else game they want. Thurs and Fri I'll be traveling to a school close to Huaraz. It's really exciting to know that work is starting. While I enjoy being a tourist, I need purpose! The hardest part of this whole thing is going to be working in spanish all day. Voy a saber el idioma muy bien despues de este trabajo!
After our meeting, we strolled around the town. I got a picture of this little girl carrying a puppy, soooo cuttteeee! Hope got a haircut for about 1.80$. Now that is cheap! We then strolled through the market, where they have vegetables, random other stuff, and DEAD ANIMALS! Lots of ducks, pigs, cow tongues, and GUINEA PIGS! I love developing country markets, they make me want to be a veg! After the market, we strolled back to our hotel. Hope stayed there while Josh and went to hunt down a better map of the areas that we would be going to. We discovered that since the area we were heading to is not a tourist area, there are no maps. To combat this lack of direction, we will each be accompanying the teacher to their school. Should be an adventure, because not only do we have to take long bus rides, but these are accompanied with long walks (30 mins +).
After this we relaxed at the hotel for a bit, then went to get dinner at a pizza place. It was okay, definitely not a Pizzaiolo, but it did the job. We then ventured into a pool hall, which was full of young teenage guys, beyond the lady at the front desk Hope was the only other girl. We took an hour to play one game because the holes for the balls were about half the size of standard ones (why? I don't know, but thats why it took an hour). Josh and I had to stare down a couple guys who were eyeing Hope in a not so flattering manner. They soon stopped as they recognized the physical superiority that Josh and I possess (right?). After the pool hall we went back to the hotel to wait for the clubs to open (think 11pm +). We then visited the Zion Bar (Reggae Vibe) and then went to a Karaoke bar, where Josh and I wooed them with "Let it Be" by the Beatles. The whole place was thoroughly entertained by our off-key rendition! After this, we called it a night and returned back to our hotel to pass out :)

I would agree with you, and don't get me wrong I don't have a problem with the hanging animals, its just something new for me. I think the shape of the people might not be completely linked to the hormones in the meat though. For instance, I've found many of the native indigenous women to have a similar shape to those Americans from the mid-west. I think it might be linked to diet, but is probably more influenced by the way one lives their life. Unfortunately, I can only conjecture on these points.

Apparently today is a election rally day, and they wanted to get started early! In addition to the march bands, cars with massive speakers strapped to the top, streaked down the streets blaring election slogans. There were even a couple rallies in the Plaza de Armas (town square). At one point I even saw some sodas being distributed by a truck, where's my coke Obama?
Besides the early wake up call, I took the opportunity to read a bit more about the area and mark up my map of things to go and scout out. I investigated a cafe called "California Cafe" where they have a large book exchange and an even larger library of books. They have a cool vibe with some coaches and tables, whichever your preference. But, the best part, is they have WIFI! I'll definitely be hanging out here often. I then trotted down the street to check out a market where I can buy basic food supplies. They have some good deals. After this, I started to wander back to my hotel, where I found a couple courtyards in the middle of some blocks. They are very quaint and surrounded by restaurants and tour guide agencies. I also found a artisan market, where I can go to get some Peruvian goods before I head back to the states :)
After all the exploring I headed back to the hotel and Hosh and me headed out to go and get some lunch. We tried to find a vegetarian restaurant from my guide book, but it appeared to have been bulldozed, that or we just couldn't find it :/ In case anybody going to Huaraz is wondering, the place is Fuente de Salud on 562 Jose de la Mar. After lunch, we strolled around the town some more, picking up various provisions for the upcoming week. I bought some local cheese for about 1$ (what! so cheap!). I haven't tried it yet, but I'll let you all know how it tastes :)
At this point in the day, we headed back to the hotel and Josh and I went over the technical details for the XO once again. Just to refresh our memory. We made copies of the image for the XO and got everything set up that we might need. After going through all of this, we hung out working on various things. Then grabbed a small bite for dinner and topped it off with some Coca beer, which was delicious!
One thing I've noticed about the climate here is that is it quite warm, even though the altitude is quite high. It cools off at night, but not too much. The air is also quite dry, my lips are slowly becoming chapped :( but I've got some chapstick to combat it.

item.title: Sept 12, 2010 - What Huaraz looks like from above (Day 9)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was an early wake up call. Hosh headed off to the bus around 730am for their two weeks in the village. I switched rooms to a single one from the triple that we were sharing. I unpacked things a bit and organized them since I'm going to be in this room for about a month. I even got a desk! Thank goodness, because my back was starting to hurt from having to work on the bed so much. I tried out the cheese this morning, the closest thing in taste and texture that I can relate it to is mozzarella, although the flavor is a bit different.
After I was finished organizing, I grabbed my pack and headed off to check out a lookout over the city. It was probably about a 4-5 mile round trip walk (I'm guessing). The road takes a winding path up into the hills above the city. Eventually you arrive at a turnout for cars, that allows one to take in the whole valley of Huaraz at once. It really is quite impressive when viewed up on the hill. While the city is a decent size, you can also see that it isn't that big. It's definitely walkable, which makes it convenient to live in (don't have to take a taxi). Although I could have turned around at this point, I continued up the hill until I reached the end of the road. What I found there was extremely surprising, it was a private suburb. The suburb looked like it could have been found in military housing (a new one) development. The houses were new, the streets clean, and of course, the gate was guarded by two armed guards. We chatted for about 10 minutes and then I began to make my way back to town.
Once back in town, I was starving. I tried to go to a trekking/pizza pub to check the place out and to get some pizza. Unfortunately their kitchen was closed and since I didn't want to book a tour, I left in search of something else. I decided to return to the restaurant where I had gotten a 5 sole (1.80$) lunch a couple days before. I had made the right decision. The dish I got was a fajita-like dish with french fries (they are literally in everything), and it was so delicious. I think those guys will be seeing a lot of me over the next few weeks. I mean, I can't even cook food for myself that cheap, they also give you a soup and this apple juice that is very tasty.
After lunch I headed back to the hotel to work on some various things and relax after my long walk. I didn't do much the rest of the night beyond getting ready for tomorrow. It was nice to just relax :)

item.title: Sept 13 - First day in the field (Day 10)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was my first day of working with kids in the field in the village of San Juan de Maqui. What an experience! It really reminded me why I am here and what I am doing. I woke up at 430am (yeah, thats right mom and dad) in order to meet the teacher who I was going to be working with for the day. He met me at the hotel around 545am and we trotted over to where the car would be picking all of the teachers (and me today) up. The car we rode in was a small station wag looking sucker, and when I say we I mean 10 people. It was so packed, you wouldn't need a seat belt, you weren't going anywhere! There were three people in the front, 4 in the back seat, and then 3 in the truck area riding backwards. I was in the back, which was fine with me, but when the road is bumpy and rocky, it sure does take a toll on one's back.
The car ride lasted about an hour following a road up out of the Huaraz valley into the mountains to the west. When we got to a certain point, the teacher and myself disembarked and started walking through the hills for another 30 minutes. The village we were heading to is literally a small grouping of houses in the hills. When we eventually arrived at the small village, we were heartily greeted by the parents and children alike.
The teacher and me went into the school house, which was actually really nice. They have three rooms for the school, but since there aren't as many children anymore, only one gets used. They have a small garden and a dirt courtyard for recess. A couple bathrooms, and I use this term loosely because its really more like a hole in the ground, but it does the trick.
The teacher showed me the one laptop that was broken, and I started to flash the system. At this point the kids started arriving and began to take great interest in what I was doing. I explained it to them, but I don't think they understood me. I took a picture of them and then showed them some of my other pictures. Because they were so interested in the camera, I let them play with my camera (the point and shoot), which they loved! One of the parents brought us breakfast, which consisted of these fried bread things and fresh milk. I swear it must have just come out of the udders, because it was super creamy and super sweet, and SUPER TASTY! It was just a little warm, which was perfect for fighting off the slight cold of the morning. Although, the entire I was drinking it, I was hoping I wasn't going to get some parasite and have my insides turn into a large knot. Luckily it hasn't happened yet, so I think I'm ok.
After breakfast, the teacher began instructing the children in division and multiplication. He made great use of the calculator activity to elaborate on his points. There are only enough laptops for the 4th and 2nd graders, but I think thats okay with the 1st graders because they seemed to like the blocks more anyways. An interesting thing I noticed that the kids do is point with their middle fingers. At first I was shocked, but then realized it was just that they were pointing. At one point the kids were interested in how to say my name. Now Jeffrey is an easy enough name to say, but they don't have the Jeff word construction. Consequently, its sounds more like Heff, which for some reason they found hilarious.
After the morning lesson, I showed the 4th graders, this was while the teacher was working with the other grades, how to do multiplication by 9 using the trick that and multiple of nine under 11 adds to 9 (9*7 = 63, 6+3=9). They seemed to think it was magic, then quickly forgot it at the sound of recess. I played soccer with the boys, they seemed to like that. Yelling at me to run faster, pass it, etc...After recess we had lunch, also catered by the village. We were given a large pot of boiled potatoes and some cottage-cheese (except the curds were much finer) like lumps of cheese. You pretty much had to eat the cheese with a spoon. The kids also had this hot soup mixture of what looked like flour, provided by the Ministry. I'm glad they didn't offer it to me, because I don't think I could drink the water.
After lunch, I showed the kids an activity on the XO called Turtle art. Essentially, its a program that allows you to program art. The teacher then asked me if I wanted to teach them the activity, of course this was meant with the large sounds of pleas and Si's. So I taught them how to make a square, which took about an hour. Partly due to their unfamiliarity with the machines, but also partly because the trackpads are extremely inaccurate. I tried cleaning the ones that weren't working, and this helped, but was still problematic. After I finished teaching them, around 1pm, the teacher and I had to leave to catch the bus back to town. However, not before we assigned them homework: multiplication/division sheet and to create a triangle with the XOs. Tomorrow I will teach them how to use eToys because it lets them create concept maps and also books. This is great because it will let them write and take pictures and paste them into the books. Then they can share the books with their friends.
The teacher and I then departed and made the 30 minute trek back to the road. We caught a bus back to town. Now, I haven't been to China so I can't compare with that, but this had to have been the MOST CROWDED BUS I've ever seen on (and rode in). There was barely standing room, I stood the whole 1.5 hour ride back (took longer because it was a bus that had to stop). After a couple stops though, I realized there were also people sitting on top, who I had missed somehow. I swear this bus must have been carrying at least 2.5X the number of actual seats it had. Nothing like careening down a mountain road in an overpacked bus to keep you awake!
After we got back to Huaraz, I went back to my hotel and promptly took a 1.5 hour nap. Woke up, got some food, and prepared for the next day. Because tomorrow, it happens all over again :)

item.title: Sept 14, 2010 - A whole day of teaching in Spanish (Day 11)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was another early riser, although slightly later than yesterday. I got to wake up at 5am instead of 430am (its a small victory okay). I returned to the same village with the same teacher. We rode in the same cab, although today there were 4 of us in the truck space, it was extremely cramped, I couldn't even move. I'm just glad that we were the first ones to get out of the car. Also, I figured out the make of the car, its a Toyota Corolla extended hatchbak. They're extremely common here. The reason I checked is because our driver was adjusting one of his rims before we left, with a sledge hammer. Exactly.
Today I spent most of the day teaching the children how to use the eToys activity. The teacher was extremely into the idea of having the kids learn more about the activities while I was there, especially concept maps. For the first half of the day, I taught them how to use the eToys activity to create books. This is a great way for them to combine pictures, text, and sounds. After recess, I taught them how to make concept maps (word bubbles with arrows). This they were able to understand quite easily and by the end of the class were helping each other make more complicated things. It is quite interesting to see how certain kids grasp the concepts faster than others. It's also really exciting to see them help each other and learn together.
We were once again served breakfast and lunch. Breakfast consisted of a herb tea that is supposed to help with digestion (I don't know if that was a bad sign) and some herb-fried french fries, with a fried egg. It was extremely delicious. We had essentially the same french fries for lunch, but with rice, and also a herb soup with cheese. Also delicious. After lunch, class was ended and we trotted back the 30 mins to the bus stop. Luckily the bus wasn't as crowded today and I was able to sit in a seat, whereupon I took a nice little nap.
Upon arriving back into town, I went through the street vendors and picked up some tangelos and plantains for all of about .75$. I then trotted back to the hotel to shower off because I was so dusty and sweaty. I turned in my clothes to get washed (1.80 per kilogram) and set about working on things for the next day. Tomorrow I'll be going to a different village, Yupash, for a day of festivities.

item.title: Sept 15 - Sports Day (Day 12)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Once again, I was up at 5am for the 6am car ride. It will be the same tomorrow. I was also once again in the back of the car, but luckily there were only three of us this time. I also found out the car isn't a taxi, but one of the teachers cars. Go figure!
I was in a different village today, the village of Yupash. Its much larger than the previous one. As it turns out, only the primary grade has laptops and it was also a regional sports day for that grade. So rather than working with the laptops and the kids, we walked about an hour to another village where about 10 schools from the area met up for track and field events along with soccer games. Apparently, the most popular sports in Peru are Soccer, Track and Field, and Volleyball. The field was literally cut out of the side of a mountain and there were probably about 200+ people there between kids, parents, and teachers. It was really great to see everyone having such a good time. I took some pictures, got stared at accordingly, and chatted with the teachers. They all seemed to be happy to have me there, although when introducing me they prefaced the conversation by telling each other I don't understand much spanish. Which is slightly ironic that I could understand that part :). Either way, they were patient with me and spoke simply and slowly. While I butchered their language in return. For some reason, after having to speak so much spanish, my head literally feels like its going to split. Trying to force my brain to work in spanish is like trying to fit a square peg into a round hole!
A few of the teachers and myself didn't stay the whole time, but rather left about half-way through so that we could return to Huaraz at a reasonable time. I think they did this for me, but I couldn't understand their spanish completely :/. The ride back was quite long, but I was glad to part from my new friends because my head hurt so much from speaking spanish all day. I quickly made my way to my new favorite restaurant Cafe Yurak-Jirka for my 5sole lunch. Then I quickly made my way to a cafe I had heard about and was pleasantly surprised. The name is Cafe Andino, and it makes California Cafe look small. Its a double story place with lots of comfy places to hang out. Its got good wi-fi, which is a necessity, and a nice library. Lots of backpackers come through, so there's always a person to catch a conversation with. It's nice to have a break and speak in english for a bit. Although the highlight of the day had to be the matron telling me I spoke good spanish, which was definitely an ego booster after having the teachers tell each other I didn't understand much all day :P
For the rest of the night I plan on working on various things and relaxing. I return to Yupash tomorrow for a day of working with the kids. Hopefully the teachers won't be too disappointed with my limited spanish! Although they were super impressed once I told them I was an electrical engineer. I think that may have changed what they thought about me, because I think they thought I was just a stupid gringo here to "work with the natives" but now realize I have a purpose and just because I speak spanish like an idiot doesn't mean I am one. I think it helped that the Director of the school has a son who is studying engineering, because once his attitude changed the others followed quite easily.
Today was interesting, even though I didn't work with they kids, it was kind of a growing day. The teachers got to understand why I am there working and we found some common ground with which to relate. Right now, I feel as if I'm in the most difficult part because my spanish is getting better but isn't good enough for proper communication. I am looking forward to getting past the hard part and being at the point where we can carry on a good conversation. And I think so are the teachers :)

item.title: Sept 16 - OKay, Just teach! (Day 13)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Once again, I was up early at 5am for the 6am, 1.5hr ride in the trunk area to the village of Yupash. Today was a bit different because I had to teach two different classes, did I mention I'm supposed to be a Technical Intern, throughout the day. Literally from the start of class at about 8am in the morning to the 1pm end of the day I was teaching. Oh, did I already mention that I'm a technical intern?
I taught the primary grade and then the younger version of the primary grade. I think the difference was between kindergarden and 1st grade, but I'm only guessing here. I worked with the older kids first. Literally the opening of class was as follows:
Teacher - "Good morning class. Today we have a special guest who is very knowledgable with the XO laptops. Give him a round of applause (I thank them). He is going to work with us today to learn some new things. Ok, go ahead and teach Jeff" Jeff's Internal Brain Response - "Uh, what?!"
But I took to it like a duck to water. Although the kids were a bit quiet, I got them to open up a bit by making jokes in my terrible spanish. I asked them if anyone had any broken laptops, they didn't. So we went immediately into creating concept maps and books, like I did with the previous school. There were about 17 students though, instead of 5, so it was a bit more difficult to wrangle them. But somehow we got through both things. There were a couple students who got things much quicker, so I used them to help teach the others. I am thankful they were so open to doing so. For some reason, this group of students found making the books easier than the concept maps, the opposite of the previous school. Interesting huh? Anyways, around 11 we broke for recess/lunch. I got some food at the local restaurant (I use this term loosely). Then back to work with the younger group.
Now, when I walked in I could immediately feel a difference in energy. These kids were extremely upbeat and bubbly. They greeted me heartily and the teacher introduced me as follows:
Teacher - "Okay class, today we have a special guest, Jeffrey. Applause (I thank them). He knows a lot about the XO's (they giggle in delight). Okay, Jeffrey, just go ahead and teach them about an activity." Jeff''s Internal Response - "WTF? Again?" Jeff''s Verbal Response - "Uh do you have a preference?" Teacher - "No" Jeff's Internale Response - "Good thing I can improvise?"
Now I had been told the younger kids would be slower and not know as much, I soon found out how wrong this was. We started with some basic activities, which soon showed me that they were actually much more capable then their older counter parts. In fact they were so fast, they were discovering parts the programs faster than I could show them. I soon realized doing the maze activity was just not hard enough, they need more of a challenge. So then we worked on taking a picture and pasting it into Write, which took them about 5 minutes. Seriously, they mastered the clipboard concept that fast, wow! Okay, so that wasn't difficult enough. I immediately switched to the Turtle Art program, which was definitely a better speed. But, once again I was surprised that they found the examples (the program has about 15) in about 30 seconds. So I had to wrangle their attention back in, they were super enamored with all the different examples. We started work on created a rectangle, which they took to quite well. We were able to accomplish it relatively quickly (much faster than the first school). However, what impressed me the most were the girls in the class. They couldn't have been older than six, but they were absolute wizzes with the program. Creating the rectangle easily, mastering the program, and understanding nuances that I hadn't even mentioned. The boys were also extremely quick, but the girls were constantly running over to me saying "Were done, what next" Honestly, they were so good I was just about speechless.
After the rectangle we made a circle, and while I couldn't describe the idea of angles and radius, because they were too young. This too they were able to do quite easily. The kids were so into it, that when the bell rang they didn't even notice. In fact, it was the other teacher telling us it was time to go. I really felt at the end of the session that these kids were going to be able to play with turtle art and master it on their own. A couple of the girls wanted to take their XOs home with them. I realized right then what I was seeing, these were girls that were mastering concepts and systems that would have been so far removed from them had they not gotten these laptops. They were building skills that will surely open doors for them in the future. I know it sounds sappy, but that's the truth. Their love of the system and excitement to use it, is the stuff that will drive them to succeed and excel in life in ways that would not have been available before.
After the class, we piled back into the car (me in the back) for the drive back. In the car I couldn't help but think about the differences between the two classes and the teachers in control of the classes. The older group had a more reserved teacher who was quieter. The kids too were more reserved. The younger group had a teacher that never stops smiling and is a firecracker. The kids were similar in their interaction. It really made me think about how much influence one exerts around kids just by who you are. And while I'm not saying one is better than another, I am saying that what type of teacher you have can make a big difference in your development of interests and work ethic.
Okay, so this has been a long post, but it was stuff on my mind all day. I'm really happy these schools are so open to me and excited to learn. Thanks to the school in Yupash and San Juan de Maqui, I hope that I've made at least some small helpful difference in your lives. I only hope that the great experiences keep coming and I'm up to the task.
Upon my return to Huaraz I went back to my hotel, switched out the stuff in my back pack, and trotted off to Cafe Andino (the nice one I found yesterday). Won't do too much for the rest of the night except work. Tomorrow I'll be going to a school closer to Huaraz and don't have to leave until 9am, so maybe I'll wake up at 6am instead :P

item.title: Sept 17 - No long car ride today, just problematic children! (Day 14)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I didn't have to get up early for the 1.5hour car ride in the Cordillera Negra, although I was up at 6am. Now why was I up at this point? Because some person next door to my room decided they needed to play their guitar. Seriously.
I ended up not having to leave the hotel until around 9am for a school only a few minutes from the town center. I ended up working with these kids (5 of them) that were just out of control. The teacher disappeared as soon as the laptops came out and the kids turned into a wild herd of cats. I couldn't really discipline them so I was struggling to find something to do that would really capture their attention. I went through a slew of things on the laptops and eventually found that I was able to keep them entertained using the Charlar (or chat) activity. We were able to set up a small chat activity between the kids and the concentration needed to use the keyboards kept them quiet for a while. Although the kids were out of control, I don't blame them. Rather, its the teacher who I think is the culprit. I didn't feel like I was able to accomplish much with the kids because they were too rambunctious. I guess not everyday will be a winner.
After the school I went back to my hotel for a couple of hours to work on reports. Around 4 I went with the specialist (organizer) to talk with the teachers about my schedule for next week. Looks like I'll be out of touch during the week because I'll be staying in the villages. They are too far away to transit too and from. I don't know if I'll have any internet or what my living situation will be like. Things should be interesting :)
After talking to the teachers, I headed over to my new favorite cafe to hang out and listen to the Cal football game. A pretty quiet Friday night, which after my busy week, is just fine with me :) [mappress]

item.title: Sept 18 - Monterrey (Day 15)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was able to sleep into 7am, but since my body clock was set so early, I couldn't get past that. The first thing I did was check the Cal-Nevada game (I had fallen asleep in the 3rd), and was saddened to see that Cal had been whooped. Sigh...
I ventured out to find breakfast, which consisted of bread and yogurt in the plaza de armas. This might sound nice, except for being bothered every 5 minutes by someone trying to sell you something. After breakfast, I went back to the hotel and packed my bag. I decided that I would venture down the road to Monterrey (15 minutes by Cambio). At Monterrey they have some baths (pools) fed by a springs. Instead, I choose to walk up into the hills directly behind the pools and spent about 1.5 hours exploring. Probably hiked up about 700 feet and then across the hill to a different one and back down. It was a nice little area with a small stream that runs through the area between the two hills (and feeds the pools). It's interesting because there is a concrete water aqueduct about 12inches wide and 15inches deep for delivering water from the beginning of the stream to different parts of the hill. This makes it possible for the people living in the hills to easily obtain water.
After my hike I headed back to Huaraz, where I tried to visit the main museum. However, the lady that could sell me my ticket was on lunch, so the security guard said to come back in an hour. Really? I just headed back to my hotel to relax after my hike. After that I didn't do too much except work on various things and hang out. I'm storing up energy for my week ahead in the villages!

item.title: Sept 19 - Sunday Brunch (Day 16)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
****ATTENTION: Over the next week (M-F) I will most likely be out of contact (won't have internet). I sincerely apologize for this, but please know that if I do have internet I will make sure to post. Most likely I will not be able to do much until I return on Friday.****
Whoa, been here over two weeks. Feels way longer :P
Today was a nice easy going sunday. Got up and worked on some things until around 1030 when I couldn't ignore my stomach anymore and needed to go get food. I had decided earlier in the week that on Sunday I would treat myself to a nice breakfast. I headed over to the California Cafe, a popular backpacker hangout, for a good hearty breakfast. I got a two toast, home fries, scramble (cheese and ham), and tomatoes. Also orange juice and coffee/tea was included. It was a good amount of food, and it tasted GOOD. I decided to get the Coca Tea. Thats coca as in COCAine. That's right, the leaves are the same thing as that powder stuff (ok well not exactly). After drinking a couple of cups of the stuff, I definitely had a head buzz (which was not expected). I spent a good chunk of the morning at the Cafe working on my lappy.
Around 1230 I head over to the Archeological Museum. I went here based on the recommendation of my guide book and let me say that the book highly over exaggerated. This was about a 3 room and courtyard area of weak photos and few artifacts. This was definitely not worth my time or money. The museum back in Lima was much better. My recommendation for anyone in the area, don't waste your time. Go hiking instead.
After the museum I returned back to my hotel for a bit. Worked some more and then headed out to find lunch. In addition to lunch I bought some mini bananas (10 for .3$) to snack on later and the next day. They are quite tasty. After lunch, which wasn't that spectacular because my favorite cafe was closed, I returned to the hotel to pack my things for the upcoming week and relax.
Tomorrow I will be up for a 330am rendezvous and ride of about 2 hours into the Cordillera Negra.

item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Hi all
Just a quick update tonight. The last week I've been in "el campo" or translated, the wilderness. More or less I went a week with minimal electricity, no running water, and no showering. item.title: Sept 20 - To Quitaflor I Go (and to not return for a week)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Wow, so this was the earliest that I had to wake up in all my time in Peru. I was up at 2:45am for the 4am bus ride into the Cordillera Negra. I was lucky in that there were available seats on the bus so that I could sit with my large 70L backpack on my lap. I pretty much slept the entire way because it was so frickin early! A quick side note on the geography of Peru. There is a Cordillera Blanca and Negra. The Blanca is the one that you see pretty pictures of, it is covered in snow, a huge trekking destination, and a big outdoor adventure area. The Negra is a more arid area that gets little rain and seems to be covered in a layer of dust (including the people that live there) at all times. You canât escape it, the dust will find you. My best analogy is to imagine mountains with no vegetation except where there are farms. Huaraz is the town that sits in between them, hence its position as a great launching point.
Upon my arrival to Quitaflor, the school where Iâd be spending the day and night, we were treated to a breakfast of potatoes, rice, and instant coffee, with a side of rabbit and guinea pig. Everything is cooked in a mud/metal stove using wood as the fuel. The âkitchenâ area was a mud-walled and mud-floored shack with rabbits, guinea pigs, dogs, and a cat cohabitating in the space. However, my insides have yet to melt, so I think everything was good.
After breakfast, we headed down into the school, which was down the âslopeâ about 500 yards. Going down was easier than coming back up in the afternoon. Before the start of school, all the pupils were lined up an arms lengths apart (arms were used to measure :P ) and given the Ten-Hut command, then the at ease release. The director of the school gave me a brief introduction and then asked me to say a few words in front of the students. So in front of about 50 students I began to bumble my way through the speech. It went along the lines: âHi, my name is Jeffreyâ¦uhâ¦Iâm here to help you with your laptopsâ¦umâ¦umâ¦If any of them are broken or have problems let me knowâ¦uhâ¦Iâm happy to be hereâ¦umâ¦I hope we can learn some new stuff todayâ¦umâ¦and so on.â Then one of the kids asked if I spoke English, I said yes I did, so then he asked if I could speak it to them. I raddled off a few sentences to keep them happy. It seemed to do the trick, because they started laughing. At this point, out of things to say, I wandered over to the director, where he seemed to understand I was finished. To recognize my effort the children serenaded me with a song in Quecha (the local tongue). After this the students disbanded and made their way into their various class rooms.
I followed the 1-2nd grade class where I would be working for the first part of the day, until after recess where I would switch over to the older group of 3-5th graders. I spent the majority of the morning fixing laptops, and the majority of the after recess session doing the same. However, I got to take a break at recess to join the kids for a game of soccer. They actually have a nice little court to play on. Since I was only going to be at the school for a day, the teachers asked if we could do an afternoon session to teach the children a new activity. I heartily agreed and we parted for lunch. In the afternoon the students returned to do a joint workshop. While we were waiting to get things started, I taught them English words by point at things on my body. They were extremely interested in knowing more English, although had some difficulty pronouncing a lot of the words. This is mostly because in English there are different sounds that just donât exist in Spanish. After the English lesson, we got started with the workshop. I worked on teaching them how to create books in eToys. The kids were extremely hard workers and we plowed ahead for about two hours, until it was just before it was dark. After the workshop, we parted ways and I went to stay with the director. He gave me his room at the familyâs house. The room (see attached photos), consisted of a mud floor, mud walls, mud roof, and plywood door that was locked using a stick propped against the ground. The roof has plastic sheeting nailed into it to keep mud from falling on the person. This was only partly affected as I was awoken in the middle of the night with mud dropping onto my face. I tried to find the bathroom before going to sleep, no luck, so I just peed in the bushes.
Overall it was an exciting day, although unknown to me at the time, the first of many for the week.
Still to be added: Video of kids singing for me.

item.title: Sept 21 - A Gringo in Llanca
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was up at 5am, although I was awake long before this due to the dog barking. I used the âwater spigotâ to wash off my face. I then gathered my things to wait for the 6am bus to the next town, Llanca. Upon arriving at Llanca, one of the teachers was awake and waiting for me. We chatted for a bit until one of the students showed up to take me to his house for breakfast. Breakfast consisted of French fries, bread, and a fried egg, plus some NesCafe coffee (with lots of sugar, which is how they drink their coffee). I ate alone with the kids staring at me.
I must interrupt my traditional story to describe some observations that I have made regarding the local culture. Most often I am asked similar questions by the locals. These include where Iâm from, why Iâm here, where Iâm going, and since their elections are soon they are also curious about our system and how it works. They are also interested in the differences in prices between here and the USA. The thing they find the most interesting though has to be my ipod Touch. They donât have ipod touches here, so it is a completely new piece of hardware. Additionally, I think I am one of the few white people for miles. I think the closest people are Hosh, who are in a different village. This makes me quite the oddity. Another thing is that Gringo is a non-offensive word. It is simply a term for white people. After living in California for such a while, this takes a bit getting used to. The last thing is that the majority of people cannot say my name. The sound is just difficult. So rather, I get called Joven (young guy) or Gringo (white guy).
The teacher that I worked with today was a bit brusque. His method of keeping his class in-line was to yell at them. While this can be effective, it loses its bite after a while. Anyways, it became apparent that he didnât know how to use the laptop very well. The way he tried to make use of it was not the most logical. Additionally, he didnât know how to utilize back parts of the system. Nevertheless, we worked through things slowly, while he asked many questions. The kids were not quite interested because they were lacked discipline and I think, and this was probably a bigger part of it, any large amount of experience with the laptops. Once again, I was shown that the degree to which the kids learn is often tied to the teacher they have.
I ate lunch with another family and was served a heaping pile of potatoes. I ate them all! After I returned from lunch, I worked on my laptop for a bit, until the professors finished their lunch. They then had a bunch of questions about all sorts of things. We spent the next few hours just working on the XOâs answering any questions and learning more about the activities. I think I really helped them in showing them what the system is capable of. This really helped to change the attitude of the teacher who wasnât very familiar with the system.
After this was time for dinner. Once again, I had potatoes, rice and a fried egg along with some sugar coffee. After dinner I went to the place where I would spend the night. I spent about an hour talking with the SeÃ±or and SeÃ±ora about the laptops and lots of other things. The room I slept in was a step up in that it had a concrete floor and painted walls, plus a metal ceiling (no mud on my face while sleeping). I had to use the bathroom, and was shown to a shack with a hole; I decided to opt for the bushes for peeing again.
Another interesting day, however, things were only to get betterâ¦
[nggallery id=24]

item.title: Sept 22 - 3 hours of walking just to save the children :)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was another day spent in the small village of Llanca. I was up at 6am, at the school by 645 to wash my face (remember I havenât showered yet) and this is a good time to begin another tale. It must be noted that up until this point, I have had no food except potatoes, rice, and fried eggs. Now if you know your food groups, this means I havenât had anything but starch (technically the egg is protein, but seriously?). Now this means something very important, no fiber and no protein (I donât count the egg) in my diet for the past few days. Think about what this might do to a personâs digestive system. If youâre thinking about the inability to use the bathroom (#2), then youâd definitely be on the right track. After washing my face, I tried to use the bathroom. Emphasis on tried, because I did not succeed. Now understand, Iâve never had this problem in my life. It was a new feeling trying to use the bathroom, pushing with all my might, eyes pooping, tears down my cheeks, and nothing. Absolutely nothing. It was very depressing.
After my failed attempt to use the bathroom, I was forced to eat breakfast. Can you guess what it was? YUP, potatoes, rice, and a fried egg, BUT there was also this delicious liquid cereal. I donât remember the name, but I think it was some sort of grain (like Quinoa) with sugar and water. Delicious! However, my happiness was quelled slightly by thought that my intestines were quickly running out of room.
After breakfast it was back to the school for a day with the older kids. This group was much more savvy with the XOs, especially the teacher. We worked with the Charlar activity, using it to create a typing competition. It was really great. In the afternoon we worked with Memorizar. The students were able to play the game quite well, utilizing the mesh network to play together.
After the school day, I had lunch with another student, who lived quite a bit away. Once again I ate, yup, potatoes, rice, and an egg. They wanted to give me some more food. But I just couldnât eat it. My insides felt completely full. After lunch, I made my way back to school. I gathered my things and began my 3 hour trot to the next village. The two teachers accompanied me about halfway. I think I walked about 6 miles, including a 800 down/up in elevation. Needless to say I was completely wiped when I got to the next school.
Upon my arrival at the next school of Mantuas, I found the parents in the school house drinking like fish. They (about 13) had gone through about 3 crates of 12 (1L) bottles. I was disturbed and impressed. Nevertheless, I was given a seat with a huge plate of food. Now before you think I say that Iâm going to have potatoes, youâd only be half right. I had Cuy (guinea pig) and potatoes with a pepsi. I ate all the meat, not because I wanted it, but in the hope that it might help relieve my bathroom issue. After dinner I ventured to the bathroom to give things a go. Now, I thought I had been pushing hard in the morning, but this put that to shame. I was pushing so hard, that I was burping up my dinner. Needless to say, I did not have any success. At this point, I was really getting worried.
I headed back to the school room, to join in some beer drinking. The way they drink it is with one glass shared, passed person to person much as a joint would be (itâs the closest analogy I could think of, sorry Mom and Dad). After a bit, I was so tired I excused myself to sleep in the next room (storage room).
If I thought I was to have a peaceful night, I was wrong. Apparently I had come down with a cold too. I had a terribly fitful night of night sweats and freezing. I had to get up multiple times to pee (not normal for me), although not for #2, which is what I was hoping for. Eventually I was able to sleep for a couple peaceful hoursâ¦
[nggallery id=24]

item.title: Sept 24 - Back to Huaraz (and a shower for the first time in 5 days)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I woke up feeling great. Because I had been able to use the bathroom yesterday, my appetite had returned. The cold affecting me seemed to have disappeared as well. But, and this really was the thing lifting my spirits the most, I would be returning to Huaraz for a hot shower and some different food. Because I was up early enough, I took a bunch of landscape pictures. I then washed my face and got ready for the school day.
We worked with the kids by taking pictures of the outside and then annotating them. The kids seemed to enjoy it quite a bit and the day seemed to fly by. The teacher and myself had to leave around 12 to make it back to the other side of the valley and catch the bus back to town. It was a hard walk, mostly because once we got to the road, there were no cars. This meant we had to start walking towards the main town. Luckily a construction worker came by and was able to take the teacher (she is a mid-40s lady). This was good because it was hot and the walking was difficult. I walked for the extra hour to the town and then had to wait for another 30 minutes to catch a car back to Huaraz.
Once back in Huaraz, I met up with Hosh and we all took showers. I used a whole bar of soap. Then we decided to go and splurge on a nice dinner to celebrate our return back to hot water. It was a nice dinner where we shared our stories. Hosh had been out for two weeks in one place, so no walking, but also no water for showering. We were all happy to be back in Huaraz and took a long time to eat. We then returned back to the hotel to crawl into nice, sheeted beds. And needless to say, that was the end of a very long and interesting week.
[nggallery id=25]

item.title: Sept 26 - A weekend of rest and paperwork
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Saturday and Sunday have flown by as Hosh and myself have tried to catch up on paper work and reports. We spent the majority of each day in cafes working and enjoying the fruits of the internet. We made sure to eat lots of non-peruvian food in anticipation for what will be coming this week. We had Thai food last night that was quite enjoyable, two american breakfasts, and pizza tonight. We feel we are ready to face the potatoes, rice, fried egg food for the next week. Luckily we will both only be working from Monday - Thursday, returning to Huaraz on Thursday. Also, Josh and Hope will be much closer to Huaraz, meaning they won't be spending the entirety of two weeks out in the village.
Yesterday it also started raining, so today we made a point to go and buy rubber boots. This is in anticipation for the dust that will turn to mud when it really starts raining out in the villages!
I'll be offline again starting tomorrow until Thursday afternoon. I'll make sure to take lots of notes about all the interesting things that I'll be doing!

item.title: Sept 27 - Back into the Cordillera Negra
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was back to the field work. I was up at 445am for the 530 cambio ride into the Cordillera Negra. The cambio was absolutely packed with teachers, and they found my hiking backpack odd and heavy, but thought I was well prepared. I can settle for that! I was even able to crack a joke in Spanish. One of the older ladies was talking to me about my schedule and a guy in the back wanted to make sure that she talked to me about my schedule. Well since we had already finished this, she tried to tell him that, so I chimed in and said we had covered it. It made the whole group laugh. I was happy to have been able to do that :)
The cambio ride was about 1.5 hours with another 45 minutes of walking. Iâm working in the village of Yurracancha, which has to be at 3300 meters at least. Itâs not so warm, plus it doesnât help that it is sprinkling off and on throughout the day. Overall the school day went by quickly, even though we only worked on one activity. The children reviewed a song in the morning and then had to type it into their laptops. While I can see the purpose in this, it took way too long and the kids had completely lost their focus after a while. I think weâll be able to work on something a bit more engaging tomorrow (or at least I hope so).
The teacher is a nice guy and so is the lady that lives right by the school. Most of the kids live pretty far away, so its really just the school and the couple houses. Fairly quiet in comparison to normal. Lunch consisted of potatoes/rice and some grain soup. Not too bad overall, minus the repetition. It really started to cool down in the afternoon and standing outside trying to listen to election banter (mostly to work on my ear), got quite difficult. It must have been in the high 30s. Dinner was another type of grain soup with some bread (another staple in just about everything they eat). This is mostly for my girlfriend Liz, but the people that live right next to the school have two cats, both less than a few weeks old. They are extremely small and adorable. One likes to meow all the time, it reminds me of Zach (her cat). Iâll be sleeping on the desks in the school house tonight. Itâs definitely the biggest room Iâve ever had :)
No shower today. The toilet is a concrete hole :P

item.title: Sept 28 - From Yurracancha to Callanca (2 hours walking)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I got up around 615, which is actually kind of late. I rolled off my desk bed (which Iâll be sleeping on tonight, although in a different school). I went about getting ready for the day as usual. I packed my bags up because I was going to have to leave after school to walk to the next school.
During the school day we worked with Memorizar. This was a good and simple activity that allowed the kids to spend some time getting to know the laptops. For some reason, they are really uncomfortable with them. Iâm not sure why, but it might be with how the teacher lets them use them. The kids probably need some open time to just play with and learn about the laptops. Iâm wondering if the teacher was trying to hide things from me or not, I wasnât sure. I got an interesting vibe that he might not let the kids use them that much, but I canât really prove it. Anyways, the day went by and soon enough the kids had to leave. I was able to get a bunch of pictures that I hope came out alright. I also got a few videos. We ate lunch and I packed up the rest of my stuff and headed on out to the next school.
The walk back to Pira, and the hope was from there to catch a combi, took about 1.25 hours. The entire walk was at a slight incline. Once I got to Pira, they were having a bit of an election celebration. This meant a lot of people were in the town square, which I skirted. Needless to say, I got a bunch of weird looks for my bags and didnât stop to talk to anyone. Plus all the cars were there participating in the election stuff, so this meant I had to walk the extra 20-30 minutes to get to the school.
Once I arrived at the school, and the small town (grouping of houses?), I searched out the person whose name I had been given. I found his house fairly fast, but then found out he wasnât there. His wife was completely surprised by my presence. She had no idea who I was, why I was there, etcâ¦So I explained my purpose, and she rallied to the cause, by helping me find the keys to the school (so I could sleep there). Then she went about finding some sheep skins (they look fresh!) and blankets for which I could use to make a bed on the desks. She set up dinner with one of the families and everything. This is pretty good considering I donât think she really wanted to help.
Other than that I set up my bed, ate some food, did some reading, and generally relaxed after my hike (walk). This however brings me to another point. The city of Huaraz is a mecca for trekking and other outdoor activities in the cordillera BLANCA, not the cordillera negra. Either way, when people ask me if I will be doing trekking, I generally respond with the fact that Iâm walking to get to places, no more. Trekking will not be on my lists of things to do in my free time :)

item.title: Sept 29 - Callanca (Not to be confused with Llanca)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
I woke up today in the school house, on my bed of sheep (probably not killed long ago based on the feel of the hides :P) and slowly gathered my items. I didnât really need to pack everything up, but I did so that it was tidy. The teacher got here around 730am and we began with the kids.
Since the class consists of four grades in one room and with one teacher (this is common to most of the places Iâve visited), I worked with the older kids first and the younger ones second. This was because they are at different stages of understanding and the tasks that we were having them do were different. With the older kids we worked in turtle art (4, 5 grade). With the younger ones we worked with TamTamMini, which is really a program that just lets kids click on things to make noise (1, 2 grade). Nothing extremely out of the ordinary, except for one student. This girl is an absolute whiz. I can show her something once, and she will immediately understand it and help the other students. Iâve got some great pictures of her, so you can she who she is. Her aptitude really blew me away and I hope that sheâll be able to take herself places with it (more on this a bit further down).
The teacher left around 1pm to head back to Huaraz and I had a few minutes of down time. The kids left for lunch and I relaxed for a bit. The kids returned quickly though (quicker than I anticipated) and we got started on an afternoon session. We worked on a few new activities for them so that they could learn a bit more. My closest approximation to this experience is trying to teach a herd of cats to sit still and do tricks. What a task! Nevertheless we got through things fair enough and I sent the kids home around 445. I had a bit more time to rest before some of the students came back with their cousins. They had brought me some sugar cane, yum but too much work, to munch on. We talked, played some soccer, and I let them play on the XOâs some more while I ate dinner that had been brought to me. Oh and by the way, my meals were mostly the same again today, except for the slight confusion that caused double breakfast to show up, double lunch, and almost double dinner, luckily I was able to avert the over-fooding. That pretty much sums up the day, but I had some thoughts today that Iâve detailed below.
Thoughts on the girl who is super bright: She is awesome with the computer, and I have a feeling that this stretches to other things as well. She is quiet and eager to help. All one could hope for in a student. In short, the type of kid you want to help and see succeed. However, I am constantly wondering what chances she really has. While she does have the XO, she doesnât have access to the internet. I really wonder if sheâll ever be able to break out of the farm life, married and with kids before 18 cycle that affects many of the girls in the area. While I believe the XO is helping, I really do wonder its long term affects and ability to help kids elevate their lives beyond what their parents know. Which takes me to the next thought. Thoughts on the older kids that came by later: Two students with their two older cousins came by after the afternoon session. I let the kids play on the laptops, apparently the two older ones (12-14) had used the laptops when they were younger and knew what to do. Seeing them use the laptops it was apparent that they knew how to use the laptop. But that is what they knew, how to use it. How to push the buttons. I have to wonder if what is being taught is how to push the buttons, rather than how to leverage the machine to work for them. I have really come to the conclusion that without the internet these laptops are nothing more than elaborate word processors. The kids arenât able to reach out into the world beyond and bring it to them. All they know is this is a cool piece of tech that nobody in their village has ever seen. This is not to say that I feel my presence isnât needed, but I think that the idea of just giving kids laptops in the hopes that they will become masters of it and their universe is indeed naÃ¯ve. That the laptop is the merely the tool, not the solution.
Sorry to get all pensive, but when hiking from place to place, one does ponder these things. Below are some AWESOME PHOTOS that I got of the kids.
