item.title: Sept 30 - Callanca and back to Huaraz
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today I was up again at 6am on my bed of sheep skins. Packed up my things and got ready for the school day. Once again, there was miscommunication and I was served two breakfasts. This might not sound like an issue, but you can only eat so much soup, rice, and potatoes before saying enough is enough. Either way, we got on with the kids and started the day without a hiccup. The older kids were to copy down a description from the board into their laptops. This was while the younger ones drew in their notebooks. Essentially, because there are four grades in the class, you have to set the kids to tasks to keep them occupied. This occupied most of the school day with the more keen younger kids joining in with the laptops. Since school only lasts until one, time tends to go by quickly in the class. I used today to also show the teacher a few things with the laptops. This is such that she will be able to better use them in the future. However, and Iâve mentioned this before, the method in which the laptops get used is very closely linked to the ability and aptitude of the teacher. In this case, the teacher did not know how to really use the laptop, and such the activities that she was assigning were not really appropriately designed for the kids. It is difficult for me to protest because I do not wish to injure the pride of the teacher and also I am not there long enough to outlast the teacherâs âassignmentsâ. Either way, the kids often do not know how to fully use the activities assigned, so I use the opportunity to expand their knowledge. I guess you could call this the compromise that I forge with the teacher (unbeknownist to them). After school, since this is election weekend, the teacher and myself walked the 25 minutes to the town of Pira to meet the other teachers and watch the election rally. In Peru, itâs common to have upwards of 10 candidates, so of course at the rally there were a couple bands. Of course, this means they play at the same time, so what was at one point indistinguishable music becomes a pure ruckus. Somehow the people can dance to it with intersperses of âSi Se Puedeâ or âYes we canâ. After an hour or so in Pira, we clambered into the Cambio (van) for the 1.5 hour ride back to Huaraz. I was in the back with little airflow, so it was hot and sweaty. However, this was not an issue, because I hadnât showered for about 5 days, so it didnât really make a difference. Once back in Huaraz, I accompanied the teachers to their candidate rally. We were able to wrangle some free beer and chicken, which was cool. It doesnât seem to matter what country you are in, but free food draws the crowd. After this I walked back to my hotel and met up with Hosh. I took a shower (the first in five days) and we went for a Indian/Mexican dinner served by a guy from northern Great Britain. He was an absolute character. Talked about his experiences with trying to do business with the locals and their inabilities to follow through. He was a bit frustrated, but full of good info. Iâll probably probe him for more info, as well as buy some of his sauces for the rice and potatoes that I will likely be eating. After a long dinner of meat and vegetables (things not found in the Peruvian diet) Hosh and I watched Toy Story 3 while surfing the internet (the drug not available during the week). On a side note, most Peruvians ask me if people in the US are vegetarians, I tell them no but that we eat more vegetables with our meals. I tell them we eat meat and other things as well. They find this odd and seem to think I am crazy. Either way, they think Iâm weird because I donât eat Guinea Pig on a regular basis, but that it is a pet. Itâs hard to explain the differences in culture sometimes. Back to the story, we relaxed and finished up the movie and called it a night. We have a few days of relaxing ahead of us that we are all looking forward to. We plan on visiting some thermal baths during the weekend.

item.title: Oct 2 & 3 & 4 - Chilling in Huaraz
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
On Oct 2 we went to the Hot Spring baths by the town of Marcara and tried to hike to a lake above them. According to my guide book, this should only have taken about 1.5 hours. However, at the 1.5hr mark we were (according to the locals who laughed when we told them where we going) still 3 hours away. So we turned back, and since the "baths" were a putrid brown, we opted for cold drinks instead. After this we headed back to huaraz for a nice lunch. I found a place with the most authentic hamburgers to date.
Sunday and Monday have been work and relax days. We spent both days in cafes (faster internet) doing reports and mentally preparing ourselves for the return to the cordillera negra. Oct 3 was election day and as a result most things were closed and people were filling the streets in support of their candidates. It was quite interesting. The weird thing is that its hard to distinguish between a happy and angry mob. We made sure to hide Hope to keep her safe (save the women I always say :)
Not much else to report beyond that. Tomorrow Hosh and me head back out into the Cordillera Negra for at least until Friday. This week we didn't have work monday due to disputed election results. Hosh will be at a fairly close school, while I will be traveling quite far. Hopefully I'll be able to make it back to Huaraz without too much difficulty. I'll have some walking ahead of me as well, at least an hour between places :P

item.title: Oct 5-7 6 hour bus ride, drunk local, 2 hour walk
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
I'm going to try a format that is a bit different, instead of posting a daily post for the past few days that I was out of contact, I will post it all in one post with sections for each day. Tuesday 10-5: 6 hour bus ride On Tuesday I was at the bus stop at 730am. I met the teacher I would be traveling with and we boarded a bus. The bus finally left around 830am. I feel the bus deserves a bit of a description. In an effort to pack as many people as possible into this bus, all large bags were placed on the top under a tarp (although this barely helps with the dust). Medium bags fill the aisle, these are things like bags of grain, dog food, and other smelly items I couldn't identify. Small bags are stowed in the above rack, or if they won't there (mine didn't), then they go on you lap. At this point I had no idea that it would be a 6 hour bus ride. Either way, the bus trundled along its way, and after about 2 hours past all the sights that I knew. We continued past the furthest town I had yet visited, Pira, and up into the hills. At this point the teacher I was traveling with made hand motions that indicated we would be traveling over the hills and beyond. I smiled and nodded my head, all the while thinking "Are you serious?". The road itself was enough to make me crap myself. It is a dirt track barely large enough for the bus (albeit a small bus) to navigate, with a several hundred foot drop present on one side at all times. Either way we eventually made it to the town of Pampas Grande (described in earlier weeks by locals as "muy lejos" or extremely far, I now know why). We had a lunch of rice and potatoes, and they set me up in a room adjacent to the church. I was then left to my own devices. I played soccer with the locals at 5 or so, had a dinner of rice and potatoes, and contented myself to reading a book in my room. *Interesting tid bit, apparently the University of Richmond sends a group of students to Pampas Grande (Article from UofR, read the article about the description town, its a bit more rosy than my interpretation) every year in April to teach the kids english and to do other community related projects. The locals thought that was where I was from. I kindly corrected them that no I was not from there, no it was not close to california, and no I also wasn't a tourist (if I was, I'd be at Machu Pichu people). I explained I was working with laptops and schools, they seemed to understand. **Double click on video to view in better resolution**
Wednesday 10-6: Chorillos On Wednesday, I was up at 6am and ready to go by 7. The teacher showed up at my room, and we did the 45min walk to the school. It was a small school of only about 12 students. They only had enough laptops for the six older students, so since there were about 4 grades in the class, I worked with the older kids so the teacher could work with the younger kids. The older kids (about 6 of them), were actually quite proficient at the laptops. However, like most students, they lacked extensive knowledge about activities. This includes the ability to search in wikipedia, how to highlight, change the size, color, font, and alignment of text in the writing activity, how to share an activity or create their own sets of flashcards. However, this group of students seemed to catch on quickly and we were able to make use of our only day together. After school, the teacher and myself trotted back to town (45mins, half uphill, think goat path). I ate lunch, and was reading a book, when I was interrupted by a yelling drunk (see video) in the town square. He kept it up for about 2 hours. I spent the rest of the afternoon reading a spanish book loaned to me by Josh (Breaking out of beginner's spanish by Joseph Keenan). A thing to note, the town of Pampas Grande is at about 12000ft. This means that at night, it gets really cold. I was wearing a hat, and multiple layers while in my room. Being inside didn't make all that much difference. [nggallery id=28]
Thursday 10-7: No motorcycle = 2 hour walk to San Juan Thursday I was up at 6am, ready by 7am, and at the teacher's house by 720am. The reason for this is that I was going to be visiting another school that day that was much farther away. The teacher was supposed to help me catch a motorcycle going in that direction. However, we did not find the moto and consequently I had to walk. We got to Chorillos after about 45mins and the teacher instructed me to keep walking on the road. So I kept walking, and walking, and walking, essentially everytime I reached a crest, I kept seeing more and more road. Eventually I had walked to the edge of the westward facing road, could pretty much see the coast lowlands, and the town was around the bend, facing completely west. After about 2 hours of walking, I was greeted by the teacher and a parent, and saw the moto I had missed parked at the parent's house. The guy said he didn't see us walking, I'm not sure how this could be because there is only one road. Either way, we got to the school and I was told there was only 4 students, and they had not had electricity for 15 days. This meant that none of the laptops had any battery left except mine. So we crowded around my laptop while I proceeded to teach them about searching in wikipedia and changing the text in escribir. Since I had to walk to the village and needed to be back in Pampas Grande by 2pm for the bus back to Huaraz (the next bus wouldn't be until Monday), I only had two hours to work with the kids. This had to include their recess the teach insisted they take. So school was over by noon. That meant it was a 1:1 ratio time walking to time teaching. I was fed a lunch of potatoes, rice, AND cuy (guinea pig). I was asked if I knew how to eat cuy (Yes Senora, I do) and if eating this food would kill me (No Senora, I think I will live). They seemed to find this funny. After lunch I got a ride back on the moto (YES) and packed my things to catch the bus. This time the ride was only 5 hours back because it more downhill than uphill. However, since the bus was much less crowded (by the way it was exactly the same bus) more bags went inside. Now, you are thinking, "Oh that's nice, less dust". And you'd be right, to a point. However, it was not for dust, but rather to make room on the roof for the pig and sheep that needed to go on the top of the bus. Now, if you've never watched (and heard) a pig and sheep hoisted up by ropes, then you are really missing something. The sound made by the pig gave new meaning to the phrase "Squeal Piggy". The sheep was more docile, hanging like a limp duck as it was raised by its neck. After these antics, the bus go on its way. Over the course of the trip, more passengers were picked up and the pig almost escaped. We had to stop (which was a plus so that I could pee) to retie the piggy. The sheep just behaved and didn't do anything. I can't imagine having to ride on top of the bus for 5 hours through cold and dust. Either way, got back to Huaraz and met back up with Hosh. Did my typical long shower routine and got some chicken for dinner. Overall a short week of work, but definitely full of adventure. Next week I'll be back in the same area, but walking to schools farther away. Good thing I'm in shape :) [nggallery id=29]

item.title: Oct-11: 3 students in the whole 'school'
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Since my work week essentially started on Sunday, I will include that day in this post. Sunday was a nice relaxing day, I woke up, did some work, got a nice breakfast, and packed to get back on the 6 hour bus ride back to Pampas Grande. I was on the bus by 330pm, the bus left Huaraz around 4, and we got to Pampas Grande around 915. For about the first couple of hours I was seated next to an oversized (width-wise, then donât come length-wise) Peruvian man. Now, this wouldnât have been a problem except for the fact that it was hot with no windows open. However, it looked like he was as uncomfortable as I was, so I guess it was a wash. For sleeping quarters, the teacher and I slept on the bus since we were going to have to get up at 5am to make the trek down to the school. The bus was cold (the town is at 3600meters) and uncomfortable, I was actually glad to get up and start moving just to warm up. Also, I really mean trek because it was about 1000ft descending, with about 45lbs of crap on my back. Imagine a donkey trail with lots of rocks to slip on, with no light beyond the flash light on my head. By the time we got to school, my shirt was soaked and I was forced to change it out of necessity (I was getting cold). Also, since there arenât showering facilities, I put on some deodorant and called it good. Plus, the kids all smell worse than me, so I donât think theyâll mind. We had some breakfast and were working by 8am. I taught the kids a bunch of new things. The kids understood things quite quickly and were easy to teach. They were extremely quiet so sometimes coaxing answers from them was difficult, although by the end of the day it was getting easier. It also helped there were only three of them, only 4 total attend the school. We worked from 8-1, donât worry the kids got a 30 min recess at 1030, and then got a 2 hour break for lunch. The teacher and I ate at one of the students parentâs house (the usual set-up), BUT the food was different. Somehow, the mother included beans in the rice and potatoes, AND cut up the potatoes to be bite sized (rather than whole), HOWEVER the best part was it had some flavor. She used something and there was flavor, and it was MAGNIFICENT! There was also soup and corn. Not too shabby. After lunch the teacher and I spoke for a bit. He was mostly curious, just asking questions about things in the United States. However, he wouldnât stop asking me about money I make, how much Iâm being paid, what Iâm paying for things, and so on and so forth. While this is normally uncomfortable, itâs definitely worse when you are trying to be discreet about your about the fact that your plane ticket costs probably as much as they make in a year. I actually saw a stat today that wowed me, the GDP in 2005 was 7$ a person in person. Iâm sure its gone up a bit by now, but either way wow. Around three we worked with the kids some more until 5. I was shown to a room at one of the parentâs houses, which actually isnât too bad. Minus the fact that the bathroom is about 100 yards away and I have absolutely no idea where a spigot for water is. Meh, Iâll wash tomorrow, nobody here to smell me but myself (and after a while, you stop being able to do that, Iâm not sure if that is good or bad).

item.title: Oct-12: How much is in your bank account?
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was up at 6am and ready at the school doors by 7am. The problem was the teacher was still asleep. So I hung outside the school for about 15 minutes eating an orange until he opened the gates. I dropped my stuff, washed my face and hair (remember no showers) which temporarily tricks me into thinking that I am clean, and we went to go eat breakfast. Breakfast consisted of a rice, potatoes, some corn, cafesito (black sugary water), and soup. Fairly standard fare. Before school started, the teacher asked me if the laptops could connect to the internet, I said yes, then he asked if I could show him how. So I showed him and showed him in the large manual provided by the ministry of education exact instructions. I donât think that he had read much of the manual. Once again, it is the case that the laptops are being used at about 50% of their capacity.
I worked with the kids from 8-1 in the activity eToys, making concept maps and books. When we stopped for recess around 1030 the teacher once again started pestering me about money and even flat out asked me how much I had in my bank account. Awkward. Either way, we had a two hour break at 1pm for lunch. We started again from 3-5 where we worked on charlar and scratch (my first group to do this with). At the end of the day the teacher told the students how lucky they were to have me and how I was paying for everything on my own. This surprised me, the paying for myself part, because this shed a new light on his money questions. For all I know he could have been asking these questions because he was concerned about me. So while I did feel awkward about his questions, it made me see them in a new light.
Also, this teacher called me by a new title, Engineer. I get a butchered form of my name (from parents and teachers) or professor from the kids, but this was the first time I got Engineer or Ingeniero in Spanish.
After school, I returned to my room to relax for a bit. At some point one of the students came to retrieve me for dinner. Dinner consisted of cancha, which is about half-popped popcorn, and some soup. There was also cafesito to top it off. While the food lacked much luster, the questions were interesting. They family, who Iâd eaten dinner and breakfast with before, finally opened up and started talking. They were mostly curious about English and how long it took to get here in a plane. This tends to be the usual fare or questions, however I got a different spin tonight that took me by surprise. As I was explaining how it could only take 12 hours and how it wasnât bumpy (remember all transportation here is by dirt road in a car or bus stuck in the armpit of the person next to you), one person asked how close to the moon we flew. Now think about that for a second, you live a life where the concept of the distance to the moon has never been explained. I was floored by the statement, but most of all, reminded why the kids and the all the people in general needed the laptops for things like Wikipedia. Where they can look up information that will completely change the way they view the world.
Also, in case you are wondering, about whether or not I feel guilty about having more than a lot of these people, I do not. Now before you fire up the email to write me a strongly worded message, hear me out. My feelings on the subject of my relative wealth versus theirs, and the amount of wealth available in the world in general, is that the pie isnât finite. One cannot think of the amount of prosperity as finite, because it isnât. In fact, I think the pie is ever expanding. And the more education and knowledge you provide the faster it will expand. So while I do have more than these people, my work doesnât make me feel guilty about this, but gives me hope that one day they can have the same sort of âwealthâ that I am lucky enough to have. While that sounds optimistic, I canât think of any other way of phrasing it. So kids, next time your parents tell you eat your waffles because children in Africa are starving, tell them that your food going to waste wonât help them, but having your parentâs donate to help education in Africa will :P (Dear parents, please donât hate me for that).

item.title: Oct 13 - Some smart cookies
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today I was up extra early at 530am and out the door by 615am. I was able to make the âshortâ trek to La Victoria in about 30 minutes, luckily it was early enough (cold enough) that I didnât work up too much of a sweat. Granted this was all downhill, so going back should be a bit more interesting. I will consider it a warm-up for the three hour walk to Pampas Grande. Anyways, I arrived at the school, but I was a bit early. I ended up talking to one of the students, probing the kid for information on how much the use the laptops, when they use them, what they do with them, and so on. This is a good way to anticipate the type of day I have ahead of me. However, I got super lucky with this school, because the kids totally rock with the laptops. The teacher came around and was extremely enthusiastic. I got a really good vibe from her. She sent me on my way for breakfast after letting me drop my bags. We started class around 8am and I soon found out that these kids use their laptops a lot. They were extremely comfortable with them and so far were the most knowledgeable of any school Iâve visited. However, the still didnât know basic things like how to copy text and photos to the clipboard. Still, there were signs that these kids were pretty ahead of the curve. One girl (the teacherâs daughter) had an external usb mouse and the kids had already dabbled in Scratch and Turtle Art, two of the most advanced activities in the laptop. Either way, I was able to teach them some new things, and all of the kids were attentive and easy to work with, even the second graders. Once again, Iâve found itâs more about the teacherâs attitude than necessarily the type of kids in the school. If given encouragement and the freedom to learn, the kids will learn. Anyways the day went by quite quickly. At recess, when the kids are normally given their government provided PapaPan, it appeared the bread had not been delivered. Considering the kids needed to be able to focus and were probably extremely hungry, I divided up the loaf of bread that I had with me between the kids. I think it was the first time they had tasted wheat bread. Most of bread they eat in Peru is flour and water, nothing more. They call it Pancito (pan means bread and ito means cute or little) and I think this is because it has little flavor. On another note, I got to watch some bulls fight during lunchtime. The owner called it playingâ¦I describe it as a precursor to animal rage. We took a break for lunch at 1. I accompanied one of the students to their house for lunch, coincidentally the house with the bulls. They are a nice family and the dad insisted I watch a running of the bulls video with him before I left. This was essentially their version of youtube. We watched people get trampled and gored. Eventually he told me that they have a ârunningâ every year in the village. Iâm glad it wonât be when I am around for it. After lunch I worked with the kids again from 3-5pm. The time flew by considering they were learning new things and really were interested in learning. After class, I played with the kids a bit, soccer as usual. I talked with the parents a bit and eventually was shuttled off for dinner. The teacher, her daughter, the matron who cooked dinner, and myself had a nice chat after dinner. We talked about all the deadly things they find in their houses, like snacks and spiders. Luckily, Iâm sleeping in the school house tonight, which is mostly concrete, so I should be a bit safer than the mud hutsâ¦hopefully. Also, I offered to help make dinner, which was greeted by hearty laughter. I think that men just about never do any of the cooking. Shoot, in some houses Iâve visited only the guys eat at the table, while the women eat near the stove on the ground. Please donât hate me feminists, Iâm just telling it as it is, and most of the time this isnât the case. After the meal I meandered the 500 yards, or the length of the town, back to the school to get ready for the next day and go to sleep. Overall, a very productive and rewarding day, hopefully tomorrow goes the same way! The whole class Local wildlife Also local wildlife, check out the teeth! Pretty Sunset

item.title: Oct 14 - 1200m up, donkey like
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was up around 6am and ready by 7am. By 710 one of the kids had shown up to escort me to his house. I took a picture of his shirt because it was John Cena, and not only was this awesome but also totally baffling as to how that shirt ended up in Peru.

John Cena!

After breakfast, it was to work with the kids. We worked on a variety of activities and since this group was so quick, I had actually prepared new material the night before. We did a quick review to reinforce concepts, then we worked on some new concepts. However, the power disappeared around 9am and consequently we were out of batteries by 1030. So, we took a recess for an hour, but upon our return, the power had yet to return. Therefore, I got inventive and did a english language workshop. I drew a picture of a person (okay, it was a stick person) on the board along with labels for body parts. Then we played a simpler version of Simon Says. The seemed to like it as they continued to be confused. We kept this up for about 3o minutes, when miraculously the power came back on. We were able to work for another 30 minutes on the laptops before the end of the day. After class, I ate lunch quickly and grabbed my bags for the walk to Pampas Grande. Jhonaton, a super inquisitive and nice kid, accompanied me for about 1.5hours of the journey.

Jhonathan

I had to walk first back to Huanlla to meet up with the teacher there. I got to take a quick rest while he got his things together.

Resting

From Huanlla we made our way slowly up the mountain, all 1200m of it, to Pampas Grande. We had to stop to take a couple breaks because the paths are extremely steep. Plus, I was carrying two packs, one with my living stuff and the other with the tech stuff. I was able to find a couple of sticks to help with the walking business, however walking still got slowly got more difficult as the day wore on. Somehow the teacher manages to do this weekly. I think I'd kill myself first.

Hike

We got to Pampas Grande around 6, and since the teacher had a stomach ache, we only had tea and bread for dinner. The bus was scheduled to leave around 2am, so we clambered in and slept for a bit until it did. This was about 730pm. By 1130pm I was wide awake, freezing (remember Pampas is at 3600m) and starving. To add to this, I think the blanket they gave me had fleas, because I was extremely itchy. I busted out my camp stove and made oatmeal. The teacher thought I was crazy, but I did not care. After the food, I was able to fall in and out of sleep until the bus started filling up with people for the trip to Huaraz. I got back to Huaraz around 730am where I promptly made for the hotel so that I could take a shower. One has to realize, the paths we are walking on are full of dust and when you sweat, dust sticks. I looked and smelled terrible. This was probably the reason I didn't have anybody sitting next to me on the bus....

Hobbits

item.title: Oct 16 - The Beautiful Llanganuco Lakes
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today Hosh and myself did a bit of touristing. We went to go see the Llanganuco Lakes at the foot of the largest mountain in the area Huascaran. Unfortunately the mountain was covered in clouds, so we couldn't really get any pictures of it. However, the lake was quite beautiful. It changes color throughout the year; it was green when we were there. To get there we opted to not do an organized tour from the many companies in Huaraz, but choose to take a combi to Yungay, the town below the lakes, and then a cab from there to the lakes. There are lots of combis from Huaraz to Yungay, about an hour, and lots of taxis hovering around to take you from Yungay to the Lakes, also about an hour. Overall it saved us about half of the cost of a trip through a tour agency. Plus this way we got to have the 'adventure' of local transportation. Overall it was a pretty relaxing day of tourismo (spanish term). The lakes Hope and Josh Relaxing On another note, I saw the Cal football team got killed by U$C. Sigh.

item.title: 0ct 18 - Walking is worse when its hot
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today I was up extremely early, like 2:45am early. While walking to the bus, I saw this - I was on a bus that was leaving Huaraz by 4am and in Pariacoto at 715am. I had put my backpack in the back compartment of the bus, which I had thought would be better than on top in terms of dust, but oh how wrong I was. I pulled my backpack out to find it absolutely coated. Note to self, donât do that again! Well I did what I could and brushed off my bag, then went about hunting down directions to Vinchota. Vinchota, the town I will be working in over the next two days is just outside of Pariacoto by about a 40minute walk, uphill and in what is best described as a desert. Needless to say I found the directions from some locals, confirmed along the way, and was able to meander my way to the school. By the time I arrived I was soaking wet, because the sun was up and it was quite warm. So I changed shirts, put on some more deodorant, and called it good. The teacher greeted me at the door and promptly informed me that he had seen me walking as he was driving his moto to the school, but wasnât sure who I was so didnât stop to give me a lift. Well, whatever, I got to the school it not fashionably late, then fashionably sweaty. I soon found out that he only has 8 students, but 5 of them are missing, so this really means that he has 3 students, all under age 8. This means that basic things like using the mouse are a challenge. However, did I let this stop me from dominating in the teaching realm? No, it did not. We worked with a variety of activities, and I use the word worked loosely, struggled through is more like it. But we got through them, they learned some new things and by lunch time all parties were in need of a good nap. I caught a ride with the teacher back in his moto, which was easier than walking, although significantly more nerve racking. We made it back to town without any hassles and I was shown to a place for lunch. Luckily it was restaurant, so the normal potatoes and rice was a bit more spiced up. I even got a piece of pork, yum. I went back to the room I was given, at the auntâs house, to take a nap (remember I got up early, donât judge). After my nap I took a 10min walk around the town to see it, this is all that was required because itâs not very large. I, of course, got stared at by everyone which is normal. I just try to look friendly and hope they assume I am. I think mostly what they are contemplating is âWhere the hell did he come from?â, sometimes I wonder the same thing. Either way, I grabbed some dinner which was more of the same fare. During dinner a local was talking to me about how Pariacoto is the best city on earth. They have the best apples. They have the smartest people. BUT, and I mean BUT, the government doesnât help them. So they canât develop a industry for their amazing apples. And their super smart people canât get educated because they donât have a university. Essentially, if the government did something, Pariacoto would take over the world. His solution was to have a new library built so that theyâd have better books. *On a side note, I havenât seen anyone reading for fun. No one.* I tried to explain that they have the internet, which is better. However, I donât think he understood that. Anyways, interesting conversation nevertheless. After dinner, I headed to the teacherâs house to confirm details for the next day. What I found out is he also happens to run the town radio station. I got to see their set-up, which would make any aspiring rapper in the south proud. They have egg cartons on the walls to dampen sound, a very small sound mixing board, and an extremely old PC for playing the songs. It is impressive actually that they run a radio station out of the guyâs living room essentially. His bed is behind a sheet! However, what this put into perspective was why he has a car (albeit it is broken down at the moment) and a moto. Heâs a teacher during the morning, and a DJ during the afternoon. Which is a great idea considering that most of the teachers only work half a day most of the time. I am never failed to be surprised, just when you assume one thing, you find out its completely different. After touring the âstationâ I headed back and went to bed early.

item.title: Oct 20 - Boulders roll downhill, don't stand in the way
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
<object width="480" height="385"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/p4l9wgvEuA8?fs=1&hl=en_US"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/p4l9wgvEuA8?fs=1&hl=en_US" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="480" height="385"></embed></object>
Today turned into an interesting day. I was up at 530am and out the door at 615am. Now, why was I up at the time when most people are still contemplating rolling out of bed to make coffee, well itâs because I was on my way to the next village. I needed to travel from Pariacoto to Racrao, which by foot is about an hour (something I would find out later in the day), but only about 10 minutes by Moto-Taxi. I had been told there was a combi or busses to be had, however, after waiting for about 15 minutes at the âcurveâ I had only seen moto-taxis. I therefore flagged one of these 3-wheeled guys down and jumped in. We took off down the road, coasting on the downhill sections to save gas of course. The thing that struck me was how green the land was becoming. The road is flanked by apple orchards and lots of other fruit plants. The green of course only surrounds the river, but nevertheless, it is in stark contrast to the extremely dusty areas I had already visited.
I arrived at the small down, think outpost, where I clambered out of the moto and became the immediate center of attention of the people hanging around. I am not unused to this since it happens just about everywhere. I asked for the teacher and was directed to her room, it was a small trudge across the street. I related my story, she vaguely knew who I was, and I was told that I could accompany her students to the school. I crossed back across the street to the group of snicker students, and they promptly began walking to the school. After about 30 seconds I realized the school was not close, but rather up about 300 meters of steep incline. Apparently half of the town is next to the road and the other is up on the ridge, connected by a trail that reminded me closely of the Grand Canyonâs trails. Either way, we trudged up the hill and all arrived panting at the school.
I was greeted by the second teacher at the school. He began talking to me like I was a Neanderthal, using large arm gestures and grunting noises. Luckily after a bit of talking he realized that I understood Spanish and promptly began communicating using his words. This was nice because it was actually harder to understand him when he was not speaking but merely motioning. I began the day working with the older students and would spend the whole day with them. As usual, the students had recess and they wanted me to play hide and seek with them. So I obliged and we began to hide. Since the school is on a hill, many of the hiding spots are on the incline. Well, I was making my way over the boulders when suddenly they gave way beneath my feet. I very quickly found myself on the downhill side of a large keg sized boulder. As I was trying to regain my footing while sliding down the slope, the boulder was bouncing against my back (not an enjoyable sensation). Luckily I was able to find some footing, spin around with the agility of a mountain lion, and parry the boulder to my side. I then watched it continue to roll down the hill for another few hundred meters. With my back itching with pain from having been smashed a few times by a boulder, the children quickly began to check about my safety.
At this point I must digress for a second, when I was about 10 my dad was playing baseball with me, my brother, and a bunch of other kids. At one point a kid tried to catch a ball in front of my dad, this kid is now in jail I believe (coincidence?), and due to his bad judgment the ball tipped off the glove and promptly smacked my dad in the face. This instantly broke his nose and sent blood spraying everywhere. My dad, a veteran of broken noses (this was his third), went into the community center and reset it. Then we finished the game. I donât tell this to describe how tough my dad is, but rather to describe the stubbornness that I was taught to show in the face of pain and danger. Should my dad have gone to the hospital, probably, did he? No, not immediately. He did go later, and had to have surgery to add cartilage back into his perennially broken nose. However, the idea is that things shouldnât stop because some serious injury has been sustained.
Back to the story at hand â Now, this is not to say I was in life threatening danger. But my back was a bit bruised. However, did this stop us from hiding and playing the game. No, it did not. We finished the game, and I finished the day teaching. Did I sleep on my side that night, you bet! (BTW my back turned out to have only scratches, and my shirt got really dirty, but whatever, I stayed hidden)
After school, I was to stay with one of the teachers (the second one I had met) in his room at the valley bottom. So we hoofed it back down to his room. He then informed me that since we had to travel back to Huaraz Thursday, we needed to go to Pariacoto to get me a ticket. As we began the walk back to Pariacoto, I could only help but think about how I could have bought a return ticket the day before. However, as I have learned in life, nothing is easy (nada es facil). While in route to Pariacoto it began to rain. So now we were walking in the rain (luckily it was a light rain). After about an hour of walking we go to town, got my ticket, and then the teacher told me that his wife was coming back to town that day. He wanted to wait for her. It was about 430pm at this point. We meandered over to the medical clinic and sat in their doorstop, until 7pm. A little under 3 hours of waiting. Eventually his wife did show up, and decided that, especially since his 4 year old daughter had come with us, that we would take a moto-taxi back.
Around 8pm we were finally back to Racrao. Since the teacher lives in one room, with his wife (when sheâs home and not working), and his daughter, things were a bit small. They wanted to give me their bed, but I vehemently protested and we hauled in a mattress from another room and I slept on the floor. There was no way I would allow the people that were feeding me and letting me into their home to give up their bed. I did not mind the mattress one bit and actually found it quite comfortable, when on my side. It turns out that like all young kids, their daughter only watches two movies (over and over): Barbie the Three Musketeers and The Little Mermaid. So we got to watch both of these before sleep. I canât believe Disney made Ariel 16 years old, thatâs just not right.
Anyways, after a long day sleep was very welcome. However, before I conclude I have to say that the teacher and his family were extremely welcoming and I am extremely grateful for all they did to make me comfortable. I know they do not have very much, but their hospitality was astonishing and I am extremely grateful. I owe them many thanks (which I tried to convey in my measly Spanish), and only hope was successful.

item.title: Oct 21 - Back to Huaraz on the road of death
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Today I was up with the teacher and his family, remember I am sleeping on the floor, around 530am. We prepared breakfast, washed up, and by 715am we were trudging up the hill to the school. Today I would be working with the younger group of kids, but the older class would also be joining us to help give them a chance to review more things (also their teacher had left the night before). To help the younger kids, I paired them up with older kids who could help them. We worked through a variety of things and by the end of the days the kids were exhausted but tired. During recess, I decided not to join them for hide and go seek, since my boulder incident was still fresh in my mind. After school, we trudged back down to the teacherâs house. I was fed an extremely large lunch by the teacher and his wife, so much so that I had to take a quick nap! The teacher and his wife were packing up for the trip to Huaraz, so I mainly just watched The Little Mermaid with their daughter. We were out the door around 4 to catch the bus back to Huaraz. The bus traveled from Racrao to Pariacoto, where it stopped for about 30minutes. I used this opportunity to use the bathroom (this is important for later in the story) and walk around a bit more Around 445pm were out of Pariacoto and on our way back to Huaraz. The ride back is on a precarious mountain road where they are doing construction. However, does this make the driver slow down or to take more caution, no, it does not. He plows through construction sites, past trucks, skimming all within inches. Needless to say after enough of these near-collision encounters, I was extremely glad I had already used the bathroom, or I might have crapped my pants at some point. Luckily, and surprisingly, we made it back to Huaraz alive and I made my way to the hotel. Before the teacher and I parted, he invited me to his house on Sunday for duck, the ducks we had brought back from his farm. Iâm excited for some fresh Peruvian duck!

item.title: Oct 24 - At Peruvian Birthdays they sing "Happy Birthday" in English
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today Hosh and me were invited to the teacher from Racrao's mother-in-laws restaurant for a birthday celebration of an uncle. The restaurant is located right next to the trout farm in the city. Seriously, its a trout farm where they raise fish for consumption in the area. The only problem is that they only way Peruvians cook their fish is fried, or Trucha Frita, which defeats the purpose of the tasty trout in my opinion. Anyways, we did not eat Trout despite our proximity to the farm, but rather were served duck. The ducks that I had help pack up three days ago. Along with the duck was potatoes and rice (I swear its in every Peruvian dish). The duck itself was not the most tasty I've ever had and I think I much prefer Liz's Grandma's recipe. I ate all the duck though and everything else. I have no fear, plus I don't want to be rude. Our main course was followed by a serving of two deserts! We sang Happy Birthday, in English, which threw me off, but luckily I knew the words. This makes me think of all the wasted time learning to sing that song in Spanish. Bleh! Luckily Deserts, Peruvians know how to get right. After lunch we all were sent into a comatose due to all the food. Overall quite an enjoyable afternoon.
I leave to go back into the field tonight and won't be back until Friday most likely. It's a 3 hour bus ride tonight, plus a few more hours tomorrow morning. I'll take great notes so that I can provide inspiring and comical posts next weekend :)

item.title: Guest Post by Hope and Josh
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
While Hope does exaggerate a bittttt, I think she does a good job capturing the situation.

SUGARCANE AND SQUARES: A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AN OLPC INTERN

Isaac and his XO laptop âHow do we know what weâre doing is actuallyâ¦doing anything?â Jeff asked at dinner. I tried to cut my chicken with a dull knife and didnât know how to answer. Josh chimed in, âYea, I mean these kids are always hungry. Girls have babies when theyâre fifteen. Itâs just the way it is. How do we know that handing them a laptop is even going to change anything?â I place my knife on my napkin and fold the corners, as if napkin origami would give me a clue. I shrug. âWe donât. Thatâs the hardest part of service. We donât know if our work is actually making a difference. You just have to do as much as you can and let other people figure it out from thereâ¦â Still stirring from this conversation the week before, I wake up to the usual rooster call. Jeff, Josh and I are teaching computer skills on special educational laptops in rural Peru with One Laptop Per Child (OLPC), and today Josh and I will lead workshops in a little mountain town called Colcabamba. The current of chilly morning air runs through the thatched roof, and I begrudgingly begin to peel the layers of alpaca blankets off my warm body. The dirt floor feels cool against my feet. Whereâs Josh? I wonder. âGood morning sunshine!â he yells from the outside. Josh is always up before me. Since we donât have a bathroom or a sink, I wet my fingers with a capful of bottled water, pop in my contact lenses using the rusty mirror, and dump the water on the dirt floor. Then I grab our little green laptops and hurry down the steps. Every morning, a different member of the community invites us to breakfast. Today, we wait outside a mud house with a bamboo roof that belongs to the director of the 19 student school. A shaggy dog sleeps at the gate. âShould we knock?â I whisper. âAnd break down the door?â Josh laughs, pointing to the hastily nailed together 2 by 4s in front of us. Finally, we hear footsteps. Itâs Mario, our five-year-old buddy who remembers every English word we teach him, enjoys sliding down dirt piles, and never gets bored of hide-and-go-seek. âHurry up!â he bring us inside, grabbing my two fingers with his hand. âGringitos!â His grandma stares at us from the kitchen and mumbles something in quechua, the indigenous language. âWhat did she say,â I whisper to Mario. âShe asked what you are doing here,â he explains matter-of-factly. I wonder the same thing.

âShe asked what you are doing here,â he explains matter-of-factly. I wonder the same thing.

We duck into the smoky room, where guinea pigs squeak around our feet, and the smell of stew wafts from a giant pot on the fire. The director has prepared a table with tea and crackers, but Mario whips out a stick of sugar cane instead. He gnaws on one end and peels away the husk with his little teeth. âHere, take some for later,â he offers, passing me a piece. I roll it around curiously in my fingers, and the teacher notices. âYouâve never seen sugar cane?â she asks. No, I shake my head. âItâs a lot of work to eat,â she explains. âHay que pasar la parte dura para disfrutar un poco dulce.â You have to get through the tough part to enjoy a little bit of sweetness. But, according to Mario, itâs worth it. My cell phone blinks 7:30, and I realize itâs time to head to school. We put our dishes in the sink and walk down the hill with the director. We will spend the first hour with the first and second graders. Theyâre not easy to teach, in part because they have short attention spans, and partly because they donât understand concepts like highlighting text or using a cursor. The kids hurry into their seats, chirping in unison, âBuenos dias!â Josh and I distribute the laptops and help the students plug them in. As we are getting settled, a little boy with sunburnt cheeks and ripped clothes shuffles in. The kids stare silently. âItâs Isaac,â they whisper to each other. Weâve only been at the school for a few days, but this was the first time Iâd seen him. âHi Isaac, Iâm Esperanza. Weâre going to work with computers today,â I kneel down and hand him a laptop.

Isaac doesnât smile like the other kids. He seems lost, like a confused and weary traveler who got off at the wrong stop.

Isaac doesnât smile like the other kids. He seems lost, like a confused and weary traveler who got off at the wrong stop. As Josh teaches the children how to use a simple paint program to practice their shapes and colors, Isaac stares at his computer. I show him how to click on a shape and draw it on the screen. He doesnât flinch. I draw a heart and fill it with red. He just blinks. Maybe heâll respond to numbers. I ask him to find the 7 on the keyboard. He takes his finger from his mouth and presses on the N key. âWhat is this called,â I ask, pointing to the heart on the screen. Nothing. âOkay, letâs try to make a square,â I suggest, as the other kids paint elaborate rainbows and outside scenes. Finally, he taps the touchpad and makes a tiny square on the screen. Something changes in him. His eyes grow wide, and he jumps up from his desk. Carrying around his laptop, he proudly points out the square to everyone in the room. âYes, very nice, Isaac,â the teacher says, leading him back to his chair. âIâm shocked he even showed up today,â he tells us while the kids work. âWe havenât seen that boy in months. His parents never went to school, so theyâd rather have him work in the fields. I think he only came because he heard weâd be using the laptops.â We spend the rest of the day doing workshops and teaching new concepts like logic and world geography with the computer programs. As the last bell rings, I canât help but reflect on Jeffâs question. We donât shower for two weeks, we live in a mud hut, our clothes permanently smell like animals, and we donât even know if our work is worth anything. The students are always attentive and enthusiastic, but I wonder if they are more excited about their new âtoysâ than they are about learning new things. Kids like Isaac will probably never go to high school or dream about bigger things. What are we really doing here? I wonder if taking one little stepâlike showing Isaac how to make a squareâmeans heâll come back to school. Iâm encouraged that we reached him, but is it enough? I wonder, as I play with the piece of sugarcane in my pocket. It feels rough and splintery; itâs hard to believe that thereâs sugar inside. Teaching here is a lot of work, I think. Pero hay que pasar la parte dura para disfrutar un poco dulce.

item.title: Oct 25 - No electricity? No problem! (at least until the batteries run out)
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Monday for me, technically started Sunday night. I was one a bus around 8pm for the 3 hour ride to Pariacoto. While most people on the bus were sleeping, I would not be that lucky. I was stuck next to this obnoxious lady that would not shut up! Everytime I was able to pass out, she started yapping again. Sigh, no sleep for me. We arrived in Pariacoto around 11 and I went to the Directoraâs house, this is also the radio station I talked about last week. I slept on their couch until about 430am in the morning, when we had to get up so that we could take a cab to the school. The cab ride itself was 2 hours up into the hills, with me bobbing in and out of consciousness due to the small amount of sleep. We finally got to the end of the road, theyâre extending it now, where we all bailed out. From there it was another 45min walk to the actual town. At about 7am in the morning, this definitely woke me up and got my blood pumping. We got to the school, and I had breakfast with the Directora. On the walk over they had told me that there was no electricity in the school (or whole little town for that matter). Additionally, they also have three classes and about 32 students. Needless to say, these are a few problems for one person to have to deal with. However, did I panic? No, I went about solving the problems in a systematic engineering manner. The teacher asked if I wanted to work with all kids at once. I politely declined (you know what herding cats is like, right?) and decided to work with one class at a time for half a day each. This ended up working fairly well, and on the second day I worked with everyone at once, using what battery life we had left to work in groups of five or six. Now, I am about to begin a rant about not having electricity, I apologize in advance. Problem 1: The town of Pallac has electric lines installed, however, they donât work. The state screwed that one up. Problem 2: There is no alternative charging system. No solar panels, no generator, no hand crank, no bike crank, nothing. Problem 3: The closest town with electricity is a 5 hour round trip walk. Problem 4: The teachers didnât know that they could take the batteries, because they are all the same, and charge them in one or two laptops back at their homes in the cities. This meant, that the laptops were not getting charged, unless kids went to the closest town to charge their laptops. Problem 5: Only being able to charge a laptop once a week, means the kids only use it once a week, meaning they never have the chance to play with and explore the system. So, a culmination of issues has created a situation where kids want to learn, but canât. Who, for the love of god, didnât research this before distributing the laptops. Seriously, the hardest part of getting the kids the laptops is done. Itâs absolutely ridiculous. Update - I wrote the Ministry of Education about this, I got a one line response - "We'll look for a solution" translation "Blah, Blah, Blah we won't do anything". Sorry if I sound bitter, but this pisses me off.

item.title: Oct 26 - Only 20 minutes to Upacoto. LIES!
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Last night was my first time sleeping on a bed made of hay. I have to say that it was actually quite comfortable and I wouldnât mind doing it again. I was ready pretty early, because the janitor had shown up early to sweep and clean the school. This is actually kind of a funny idea, considering that when he sweeps the rooms, it really kicks up more dust than anything, which leaves everything coated in dust and the room unbreathable for about 20 minutes. For the first half of the day I taught the younger kids and did a school-wide workshop after recess. We worked until our batteries were gone.

Stick out your tongue

Huh?

Check this out!

Excitement

Pallac

I was fed a really good beef soup and lomo saltado (beef with tomatoes, rice, and French fries). One of the teacherâs husbands made it and it was honestly the best soup and lomo Iâve had while in Peru. After lunch I left the school with the teacherâs husband to walk to the town across the canyon, where his motorcycle was parked. He would be giving me a ride to a town somewhat close to where I needed to go. Once we got to Pache, about an 45min walk, we found that a engineer was leaving in a car. I was able to bum a ride with him to the top of the mountain. From the top of the mountain I began walking. I had to walk to Puma (the town has this name for a reason, the area is full of Pumas) and then down to Upacoto. Before I continue, I must include an interesting conversation that I had with the teacherâs husband. Apparently the teacher who sold me the bus ticket the past Friday, the one who said that bad people live in Pallac and they would rob me, was also the same teacher that got removed from hitting her students. And then, when confronted by parents, hitting them too. So apparently, she wasnât entirely truthful about the people being bad. Like the teacherâs husband said, âIf you are open to the people here, they are open to you. If not, then they wonât beâ. I think that this is true everywhere, if only we had the community mentality to deal with the problems like the people of Pallac do. The walk to Puma was relatively easy. It was all on a road that was mostly flat. It took me a little over an hour. When I got to Puma, I got directions to Upacoto, which pretty much consisted of âTake that pathâ. When I asked how long it would take, they said 20mins. This was a lie. I began walking on the path, which quickly turned into something even a goat would have trouble with. The path soon disappeared and I was stuck sliding down a hill on my feet as I made my way towards Upacoto. Eventually, and after about an hour of hill sliding, I was at a point where I could cross the stream/canyon barrier and begin to quickly make my way to Upacoto. The overall trek took about two hours from Puma to Upacoto. Not exactly the 20mins I had been promised. It was one of the most difficult walks Iâve done so far, although the hike up from Huanlla to Pampas Grande still takes the cake. For full effect, you should watch the video (coming soon). I arrived at the school, where the teacher was pleasantly surprised to see me. She politely informed me I was a week early. Well I showed her by pulling out my schedule, and the schedule won! Okay, so it wasnât quite that dramatic, but she was a bit surprised. Nevertheless, she turned out to be one of the nicest teacherâs Iâve met and we moved past this hurdle without a problem. She was even nice enough to give me her room, and she went to stay with one of the parents. Super, super nice. I talked to a bunch of the parents, fielding the usual questions, and then got some dinner. I was so exhausted from my walk, that I promptly passed out after dinner because I was so exhausted. Oh, and for those of you worrying if I was sweaty and dirty, yes, I was. BUT, I rinsed myself in the sink before dinner so that I was a bit more presentable.

item.title: Oct 27 - No electricity, again :(
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was woken up by what sounded like robbers at 530am. I stumbled out into the courtyard of the school to find two students cleaning the school house. I think I scared them as much as they scared me. We exchanged brief hellos, and then they got back to work. Since I was up so early, I went stick hunting. After having slid down the hill yesterday, I promised myself that I would build myself a walking stick that even Gandalf would be jealous of (LOTR reference anyone?). So I hiked up the hill behind the school a bit and soon found a suitable candidate. There a literally hundreds of stick lying around from all the cut down eucalyptus trees, that are used for firewood when it isnât raining. Eucalyptus makes a fairly good walking stick because the bark comes off quite easily. I spent a good hour working on the stick until a parent showed up to take me to breakfast. I followed the parent the 5 minute walk to his house (along a goat path on the side of a hill of course) and was soon gorging myself on rice and potatoes, nodding and smiling the whole time to let the parents know how delicious it was. Of course, inside, I was dying a bit wishing I could get a sausage and some proper hash browns. BUT, when people who are extremely poor feed you food, you eat it, you love it, and you tell them every minute how good it is. After breakfast, it was back to the school for the morning lesson. Since Upacoto also does not have electricity, I quickly decided that the eight students would work in pairs with the screen brightness turned all the way down.

Working in Pairs

The XO has a pretty neat feature that allows the screen to turn into a black/white screen much like the amazon kindle. This really helps to save battery life. We were able to breeze through a bunch of things before recess. I was working at breakneck speed because I knew that battery life was my enemy. But the kids took it in stride and soaked up everything like sponges. During recess I finished off my walking stick, giving it a sharp point on the top, in case I had to fight any Pumas (or people who took a liking to my bags). After recess, we breezed through more things and before we knew it, the day was over (at 1pm). I grabbed some lunch with a kid and soon found myself sitting by the creek in the sun reading my book. I spent most of the afternoon here relaxing. Very enjoyable. I spent a couple of hours photographing about four of the students while they played. By darkfall, I had hundreds of photos. The kids were so photogenic I just couldnât stop myself. Eventually I was led to dinner, where once again I gorged on rice and, wait for it, potatoes. item.title: Oct 28 - Lots of walking = smelly shoes!
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today I was woken up again at 530am the robber cleaners. I cleaned up, took some photos of the sunrise, and was ready to go when school started.

Sunrise

I anticipated that we would only have battery sufficient for about 2.5 hours at most, so I told the teacher I planned on leaving around recess. She agreed, mostly because walking to Cochabamba, where I could hopefully find a car would probably take about 2.5 hours. For the morning session, I did a review with the kids and then was able to cover some new topics. I felt that I had to rush, but didnât have a choice. I think the kids got quite a bit out of the workshops and only wish they had electricity so that they could explore their laptops further.

The class of Upacoto

When recess showed up, I suited up â big backpack on back, small backpack on front, and now walking stick in hand â and was off. I was accompanied by three of the older students who were to serve as my guides. Since they were about half my size, I felt like Gandalf and they were the hobbits. I didnât try to convey this, it would not have translated well I think. They walked with me for a little over an hour to the top of the ridge, where they pointed out how to get down to the town. As a parting gesture the oldest one asked to be paid. I laughed and told them that they could have candy but that I would not give them money. After this, it was mostly downhill (which starts to hurt oneâs feet after a while) until the town. I got to town at about 1245, but unfortunately there was no car. Soooo, I kept walking down the slope to get to Pariacoto. After about an hour or so, a car happened to come by. Luckily, it was filled with teachers who knew me, and I was able to pile into the trunk area. After about 15 minutes (which would have been probably another 1.5hour walk) we were in Pariacoto. I am lucky a car came by, not because I was tired, but because my feet were starting to hurt. After walking downhill for so long, they felt completely pounded. I think I might have lost about an inch in height during the day, not a good thing for me! I got lunch with the teachers and then we waited for another couple of hours for the bus. Eventually the bus showed up, we fought for seats (Peruvian buses are not for the faint of heart, or poor old ladies), and by 5pm were on our way back to Huaraz. We got back to Huaraz around 830pm and I made my way to the hotel. At the hotel, they told me they were full, and to come back the next day. The owner has another hotel that he recommended going to, but since Hope and Josh had already been there and described how much is SUCKED, I decided to go to our back-up hotel, the hotel Las Vegas (reminds me of RaÃºl, a friend in LV doing TFA). While the hotel Las Vegas has much faster internet, it is also close to the market which makes it a bit louder. However, this didnât bug me much in comparison to my shoe smell. Imagine shoes that are dusty and sweaty and donât get changed for weeks, do you feel your nose wrinkling? Well, my did when I took them off my feet, so I got some incense to burn to combat the smell. It worked surprising well and Iâll make sure to get some talc powder for my shoes to help combat the smell further. The funny thing about being away from the internet for a few days, is when you get it back, youâre like an addict. You stay glued to it for hours, doing nothing but getting plugged back in. Well, I was up late on the intertubes and fell asleep disappointed I did not have more energy to keep going. Overall, a long, very trying week, but satisfying. Everything one could hope for from such an adventure.

item.title: Oct 30 - A day in Lima with some new friends
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today we rolled into Lima around 6am. Our bus stopped at their bus terminal, and we clambered off grabbing our stuff. Then the bus left, which we thought was odd. We were soon attacked by a mob of taxi drivers. We inquired about prices, and they quoted us a huge and large sum. We laughed at them, but then they informed us that we were in old lima, north of the city, rather than in the middle of the city, at the other bus terminal. This was a surprise, since no workers on the bus mentioned that there were two terminals. Anyways, instead we got a cheap ride to the "subway", which is really a dedicated bus lane that moves pretty quick. We were able to bus down to where our hostal is located, and then walked from the station to the hostal. We ended up picking a hostal named HQ Villa, which was a great decision. This place is literally a villa with comfy couches and a great breakfast! Only about 7$ a day too, when sleeping in the dorms. We ate some breakfast and got ready for our day. I had been in contact with some local LimeÃ±os via a service (website) called CouchSurfers. We decided to meet up and soon enough we found ourselves in the back of their car getting a private tour of the city. We grabbed lunch at a arabic restaurant, which was a smart and tasty decision. After lunch, our guests took us back to their house where we chatted for a few hours. It was really interesting to see how more well-off Peruvians live, considering most of our time is spent with the other side of the social class. This is very different from the ways that they live, the fun they have, and their opinions that they have on their country.

Hope+Josh

We were eventually dropped off back near our hostal, where we met up with some friends to watch the world series. The two girls I speak of, were ones we met when we were first in Lima. They are both doing Fullbright scholarships/projects. It was great to catch up, eat a nice steak, and watch some baseball. We met at TGI Fridays, so it was a nice reminder of home. The workers at Fridays were decked out in some serious Halloween garb, which was cool to see. The bartender could do some pretty cool tricks too, which kept us entertained.

Steak Noms

After dinner, we got some churros, which they fill with different fillings here. For instance, vanilla or manjar blanco. This makes them quite tasty and also super sweet. However, every once in a while won't hurt you. We got back to our Hostal around 10pm where we spent some time on the internet, and since our bus ride the night before had meant we hadn't slept that well, were in bed by 12pm. Overall, a long and enjoyable day. It was just the type of thing we need to give us a break from our normal routine. I'd like to specially thank Ana and her friend Jesse for taking us around and showing us a great time. We are really thankful for all the time you spent with us!

item.title: Nov 2 - My stomach wants to kill me
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This week really began on Monday night. Hosh and myself had arrived back in Huaraz around 6am in the morning. We trudged our way to the hotel, and all took a nap until about 10am. While the bus trip from Lima is advertised as a âbuss camaâ or bed bus, sleeping is minimal at best in my experience. We spent the rest of the day relaxing and working. Around 6pm, I met the teacher with whom I would be traveling and we piled into a combi for the three hour ride to Cajamarquilla. I would be working at the same place all week, since the places I was scheduled to visit were too distant and would have had to walk for too long a period of time (not that that is really much of an issue anymore). Now this particular combi trip was exceptional in that it had to be the MOST CROWDED combi I have ever been on. They should only be able to hold about 14 people, we had 22. In addition, the roof was piled up about 3 feet high with cargo, and the entire inside walkways were filled with bags. Honestly, I could not move an inch. Throw in the fact that the seats have about no padding, which means you are riding on metal bars, and you have a recipe for a very uncomfortable three hours spent on small dirt mountain roads. Nevertheless, we arrived in Cajamarquilla without a hiccup, thank god, and I was shown to my room. I promptly passed out. I awoke Tuesday morning feeling like someone had kicked me in the stomach. I had a terrible case of bubble guts that would only get worse throughout the day. I rallied, got ready for the day, and by 630am was walking with the teacher up to the school, located in Shipash Huain, a 45 minute walk uphill. By the time we got to the school, of course I had worked up a good sweat in addition to my stomach that would not stop talking. Seriously, it was making noises. I suffered through breakfast, not because the food was bad, but because I had almost no appetite and any bit of food that hit my stomach felt like the equivalent of getting punched. After breakfast, I worked with the kids until 1pm in a couple different activities. The students themselves were typical of most I had encountered. Some were quick to learn while others needed much more help. Usually the ones that understand help the others, which is helpful to me since I work alone. However, the biggest problem with this is that the students who need the help, tend to just become reliant on the help and wait for it, rather than taking initiative. While normally I would not permit this, my time is limited, and I have to make compromises.

Working

Youngin

Youngins

Youngins

During recess, their ball got stuck on the roof of one of the buildings. To get the ball down, and here-in lies the difference between the US and here, we used a piece-mealed ladder propped up on chairs to give it more height. One girl climbed up onto the tin roof, which is not the most structurally safe structure I have ever seen, and grabbed the ball. Never, ever, in a million years, would a kid be permitted to do such a thing in the States. Not only because itâs dangerous, that can be overlooked, but because someoneâs lawyer will sue if anything happens. However, if you have only one ball and you live in a place where the only law is that which the community enforces, then it just doesnât really matter. We had a quick break for lunch. The teacher made a large amount of food, which I was only able to eat half of before I wanted to curl into a ball and cry like a little girl as my stomach did circles like a washing machine. She understood though, and knew that it didnât have to do with my dislike of the food. In fact, I was eating better than I had in weeks. We had chicken and vegetables. Of course it makes sense then, that when I get good food, I donât feel like eating. Typical. We finished up around 430pm, and made the trek back to Cajamarquilla. As soon as we arrived I passed out in my room. I woke for dinner, where I only drank some tea, and then immediately went back to sleep. My sleep was periodically interrupted by the need to use the bathroom (itâs what you think it was, although probably worse), but by the time I woke up the next day at 530am, I felt like a new man. My stomach had stopped hurting and everything felt back to normal. I can only speculate what the cause of this temporary sickness was, but I think it was a combination of altitude (we were at about 3800meters, Lima is 0meters) and the large amount of red meat I had had in Lima. Oh well, all part of the adventure.

item.title: Are laptops the most important thing?
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Many of the villages that I have been visiting live with the most basic of needs. The rarely have running water in the small aqueduct systems. They eat potatoes and rice for every meal, usually accompanied by soup and cafesito (boiled black water with sugar). They eat off the floor or their laps. They rarely shower or bathe. Washing oneâs hand is rare and fingernails are always dirty. Dust permeates everything and the smell of farm animals clings to the people. The houses are made of adobe bricks with perhaps one light bulb in a building. Due to these harsh and most basic of conditions, medical care is basic and extremely limited. When one is sick, your remedy is often eucalyptus tree-leaf tea or any other combination of herb water. While these sometimes help with the occasional stomach ache, they do not help with other diseases or ailments. Many of the kids suffer from serious bouts of warts. The warts cover the hands, often numbering upwards of 15 on a single hand, and with sizes sometimes approaching a dime. There are no cures for this. They cannot burn them off with super-cold liquid nitrogen. They cannot sear them off with a heat gun. All they can do is permit the warts to grow and spread without check.

Besides warts, the other most prominent ailment is frostbite on the kidâs hands and faces. This will create hands covered in scabs and checks that are affected the same way. This give the kids rosy cheeks, while in reality they are really just scabs. Combine this with dirt and you have some very unhealthy looking skin.

The last thing that affects the kids is diarrhea. They drink the water from the tap and the streams, which are contaminated with animal feces. This results in making the kids sick to the stomach. While they confess to being used to the water, this is only partly true. It is never possible to be completely used to contaminated water. These three things are only a few of the many medical issues that plague the communities. While they are a big problem, sometimes I have to wonder if teaching kids to use laptops might not be the most pressing matter when they suffer from other physical ailments.

item.title: Hunger
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
The kids in the schools do not eat very much food. This is not to say that they are not hungry, merely that they do not have a large amount of food to eat. The school day itself is limited by this fact. School typically lasts from 8am to 1pm. Sometimes kids will return in the afternoon for a couple hours, but this is dependent on the teacher, school, and geography (whether or not travel is easy enough to return). The kids will have a small breakfast at home that at most consists of a few potatoes and some Arina (what to me seems like the liquid part of oatmeal). They then arrive at school and will get a small snack at lunchtime. This will consist of government provided bread known as papapan (father bread) and some fortified white liquid drink prepared by one of the mothers of the students (the powder to make the liquid is also provided by the government). They call this liquid leche or milk, however it taste more like liquid dough. While neither of these things is a tasty endeavor, the kids inhale all of it quickly because they are starving. Both of these items are provided by the government, because if the kids did not have this snack, they would not eat anything until dinner time.

item.title: Nov 8 - Another hike to the last place in the "Campo"
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today, although I did not have to be up early, I was awake by 6am due to some blaring music coming from another room. I roused myself and began packing. The teacher came to the hotel around 9am so that we could head to the bus. We made a few errand stops on the way, and were at the bus stop by 930am. The bus was due to leave at 10am, it was out of the gate early at 1030am. What amazed me most about this is not that the bus was late, but that I have become accustomed to it. It doesnât really faze me anymore. However, this might be due to the knowledge that whether or not the bus leaves on time, I still have to sit on it for about 3 hours (or more). Whatâs the rush? Wait here, wait there.
For Monday and Tuesday I would be working at a town called Coltus. On the map given to me by the specialist, this was the one furthest away. While the bus ride wasnât the longest, that was the one to Pampas Grande (6 hours), our 3 hour bus ride was not short by any means. When we arrived at the point we needed to disembark, we still had another 2 hours of walking ahead of us. Our trek took us up the mountain side (35 mins to about 4300meters), across the plains along the top of the hills (90 mins), and back down the other side (45 mins to about 3800meters). Luckily it was quite a nice day, and although brisk, the walk itself was not too difficult. Time passed somewhat quickly as I talked to the teacher about his previous job as a Guide in the area. Out of curiosity, I asked which tourists were the worst, without hesitation he replied Israelis. That was the same thing the mountain bike guide said. A pattern perhaps?
During our descent to the village, itâs really only a gather of mud houses, I noticed one important thing: no power lines. The first thought that went through my head was, again? However, when I asked the teacher about the power situation, he informed me that they had a solar system. Awesome! I asked how he got it, thinking that maybe the government had gotten their job right. He replied that some random group of 3 volunteers from the University of Michigan showed up about 7 months prior to deliver a system. They came on their own and the government had, and still does not have, any knowledge that they were coming. Random huh? Well luckily, that means we can charge laptops. I asked what the teacher did before this and he told me that he would carry about half the batteries, but only half, because they were heavy. This meant the laptops could only be used for at most one day, now they can be used every day. Props to the people of Michigan, well done guys!
After we rested a bit and had a snack, it was beginning to get dark. This was also accompanied by the loss of all warmth as it became very cold, due to the altitude is my guess. This did not deter the villagers, since apparently, they gather to watch movies most nights in the school. One of the parents has a generator with which to power the TV and DVD player. We ended up watching âClash of the Titans,â which in my opinion is a weird situation. Here I am, in rural Peru, with people who have probably never heard of Greece, watching a Greek myth. I think the story was somewhat lost on them. Either way, the original version is definitely better than the new one that came out recently, so if youâre going to watch Perseus kill Medusa, watch the original. After the movie I set up my bed of sheep skins on the floor of one of the school rooms, crawled into my sleeping bag and passed out. While this may sound somewhat dirty, and it is, it is also super warm, so I cannot complain.
