item.title: Dec 7 - On to Aguas Calientes
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
The first part of the day was slow and easy. We did not have to be on our train to Aguas Calientes until 1230pm, so we spent the morning packing and eating Choclo con Queso, Maize with Cheese. By the time we actually got on the train, there was a slight drizzle, which didnât let up until much later in the afternoon.

Train Ride

A quick note on the logistics of Machu Picchu, if you arenât interested, simply skip past this section, but the overall logistics are quite interesting. Machu Picchu itself is located up a valley that is only accessible two ways: by train or by hiking the Inca Trail. While I have heard rumor that you can take a colectivo, this manner is most likely limited to locals and has been known to be very dangerous. The geography itself demands that there are no roads, plus I think Peru Rail enjoys the monopoly it has over the service. There are two companies that one can take, Peru Rail and Inka Rail. Peru rail is the biggest and most popular, offering multiple types of services and times. There is a highly exclusive level that leaves and returns to Cusco costs about 600$ roundtrip. The next level is slightly more reasonable and leaves and returns to Ollantaytambo for about 180$ roundtrip. The cheapest option, cheerfully dubbed the âBackpackers Trainâ (really thatâs the name, Iâm not making it up), leaves and returns to Ollantaytambo for about 63$. Inka rail is about 90$ round trip, with similar service. The trains themselves donât go to the site of Machu Picchu. They go to a small town at the base of the mountains, next to the river, called Aguas Calientes or Machu Picchu Pueblo. I think they are trying to rebrand to the latter, but are not having much success since everyone I talk to calls it by the former. AG is a town built almost exclusively to serve tourists on their way to MP. There are places to eat, places to stay, and places to shop. Not much else. The good thing is that if you are in the low season, haggling is extremely easy, as all the restaurants and hostels are fighting for business. The tickets for MP have to be bought in AG and cannot be purchased at the entrance to MP. The tickets are 44$ for adults, or half that for students. To get to MP, one can either do the 1.5hr walk up to the entrance or pay the 7$ (expensive by Peruvian standards) to take a 15min bus up. Buses run from AG up to MP about every 15 minutes, after the initial morning rush. The first buses leave around 530am, which means if you want a decent spot you have to arrive about 45 minutes early to line up to get on the bus. You have to buy a bus ticket before getting on the bus and can either buy a roundtrip ticket, or a one way. If you are in decent shape you can hike up and hike back, but Liz and I decided to only hike back (downhill is so much easier). Once you get to MP you have to queue up to get into the site. The guards come down the line asking if youâd like a ticket to climb Huanay Pichu (the mountain behind MP). They only allow 400 people total to do this a day, so if you are not early, you canât get a ticket to do this. Many people hiking the Inca Trail cannot get these tickets during the high season because they arrive a bit after the bus crowd has arrived. In fact, to get a decent spot and be there early enough to avoid crowds, one has to stay in AG to get up to MP early enough. If you come on morning trains, you donât arrive until around 10am, and if you hike, you still donât arrive until about 630-7am. Itâs a very convoluted process that took quite a while and many discussions to figure out and decipher. However, once deciphered, you get treated to one of the new Seven Wonders of the World. Now back to the main story. The train ride is very scenic as it slowly tracks farther into the mountains. The hills rise up vertically, reminding one of Jurassic Park (or Kauai if youâve actually been there, which is where Jurassic Park was filmed). The area is known as a cloud forest and is extremely green (stark contrast to the Cordillera Negra). Besides the scenery, the only other memorable thing about the ride was the coffee, which was atrocious. Absolutely atrocious!

Peruvian Countryside

Once in AG, you disembark and are immediately bombarded by people trying to get you to come eat at a restaurant, stay at a hostal, buy copied painting prints, or any other myriad of things. The entrance to the train station is surrounded by an artisan market, which means to actually get through the town you have to slug your way through a series of stalls and people trying to get you to buy useless crap. Once Liz and I had made it through these various layers, we set off to buy our Machu Picchu tickets and find a place to stay. We were able to swing the student price with our old Cal student IDs for the tickets, which was half-off. This was pretty cool. After this we went on the hunt for a hostal, which turned out to be quite easy. Once one wanders out of the plaza and into the backstreets, one can encounter a myriad of places all looking to serve your needs. Originally Liz and I had planned on camping, but due to the rain we decided against this. We are both familiar with sleeping in a tent in the rain and needless to say, unless forced, it is not something we would willingly do. Once we found a place with the appropriate price and amenities, we went for a walk around the small town. We had a late lunch, which actually ended up costing us less and having free Pisco sours. Although the restaurants in the town try to charge a service fee, when I saw this on the check, I told the waitress we were not going to pay it. She tried to lower it, but I said that we would pay no service fee, none. She gave up fairly easy which makes me think they just try to do that to get more money from people that donât look at the check. On a side note, it is not customary to tip in Peru, which is why I argued the fee. After lunch we got food from the market (which is surprisingly well-stocked) for dinner. We looked at some of the shops and generally killed time throughout the day. The town can be walked end-to-end in about 10 minutes, so it is not entirely the largest place. After our exploring, we returned to the hotel to pack and prepare for the big day at Machu Picchu the following day.

item.title: Dec 8 - Machu Picchu
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
To Machu Picchu

Today is the day, the day that Liz and I would see the most famous place in South America, Machu Picchu (MP).

Machu Picchu

As with anything that is extremely famous and well-known, we had to be up early. Liz and I were up at 345am and out the door by 445am. We walked the block or so to the bus station where we grabbed a place in line. We were not too far back, which was good to know. As we waited for the 520am hour to strike, we listened to music and stared at the wall. Eventually the time came and people began filing onto busses. While shuffling forward we heard the words yelled out âHave your bus ticket in your hand,â to which I thought, âWHAT?!â I had been under the impression, based on my myriad of experiences with Peruvian transportation, that once on the bus we would pay the fare. I was very wrong. After talking to one of the guards, he informed me we had to buy the tickets at the booth. Well, I ran to the booth, where I had to wait in-line for about 10 minutes to buy the tickets. By the time I finally got the tickets, we were the last two people on the last set of early morning busses. Good luck or bad luck? Iâm not really sure, but I did feel like a dumbass (which was not helped by Liz snickering). Once on the bus, the 15min ride was easy and quick. When we arrived at Machu Picchu, we got into the queue to wait for admittance into the famous site.

Morning Clouds

We got our tickets stamped so that we could climb Huanya Pichu (HP), the mountain peak behind Machu Picchu (itâs in all the photos pretty much). Once at the entrance we had to show passports and our student IDs, which is the most rigorous ID check Iâve had in Peru.

Ruin Walking

Once inside the gates, we made our way quickly to the back of the site, where the gates to HP are located. We were the first few out of the gate and the first at the top.

Huanya Picchu

The climb is almost vertical although quite short. What takes most people about 45mins, took Liz and I only 20. Why you might ask? Because weâre awesome! Why else?

Afraid of Heights?

Once at the top of the peak, the view is truly amazing. One can take in all of MP and the surrounding valleys and mountains.

Machu Picchu and Me

There are clouds whipping up the face of the mountain, giving the site a mystic feel. The river rumbles far below the sheer cliffs that surround the site. Liz and I had timed it right, as we arrived at the top right as the sun crested the hills and shown down through the clouds onto MP. Not only did it give me great light for photos :P, but it also was amazingly beautiful. Since Liz and I were some of the first up, we had a good deal of time to simply take in the sight without interruption. Truly, a once in a lifetime experience.

Machu Picchu

After HP, we made our way slowly back down the vertical, wet, slippery stairs and up the small mini peak over MP. While there was nobody on this small peak (most opt for the bigger one), it did provide another great view of the site.

Inca Cola & Machu Picchu

Eventually Liz and I were back in the site itself, where we could wander among the buildings. The buildings, architecture, layout, stonework, and almost every other facet (including the tourist density) is unlike anywhere else in Peru.

Mach Picchu

While MP is somewhat like a tourist trap, it is also a one-of-a-kind place that cannot be understood until visited. Until you look out from the main plaza, or temple of three windows, into the vast mountains surrounding the area, you cannot understand the power of the place.

Liz at Machu Picchu

Plus, why give up climbing hundreds of stairs over the course of the day while looking at the ruins? Although, you do begin to feel bad for the elderly visiting the site, I mean, climbing rock stairs at high altitude is hard for anybody. After spending about 7 hours wandering through the site, playing with Llamas, and taking hundreds of photos, we left the site and began the hike back down the hill.

Admiring the view

Llama beak

The hike down the hill is mostly steps and took us about 35 minutes. The whole time it drizzled, up until we reached the bottom, when the sun came out. Typical. We grabbed lunch since we were starving and headed to a cafÃ© to hang out until we could leave by train. When we grabbed dinner, it actually induced some serious stomach pain for Liz, so we rested at the train station for a couple of hours until the train took off. Once back in Ollantaytambo, we got a colectivo back to Cusco. By the time we were back in Cusco (2am) we were exhausted and made a bee-line for the hostel. Once there we didnât even bother to shower, but just plopped down in bed and passed out. Despite the stomach pain and late arrival, it was an amazing day.

item.title: Dec 13 - Goodbye Peru, hello Ecuador
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Today was all about travel. Liz and I flew from Lima, Peru to Guayaquil, Ecuador. The flight was on LAN airlines, which I must say, is a great airline. Every plane has a TV in the back of every seat and the service is excellent. You can catch LAN flights all over South America for reasonable prices. I highly recommend them if you find yourself in a position to buy a ticket with their company.

Ecuadorian Greenery

When our 2 hour flight to Ecuador arrived, the biggest difference we felt was the weather. Whereas Lima is temperate, Guayaquil is hot and sticky. I quickly regretted my choice of pants. After getting through customs, which was punctuated by extremely pushy and fussy old ladies who kept trying to cut me in line, we grabbed a cab immediately to the bus terminal. Now, when I say bus terminal, I really mean terminal. As in, terminal like an airport terminal. They have lots of food stalls and large waiting rooms. There are hundreds of buses in a brand new building just waiting to whisk their passengers off to other parts of the country. The bus travel itself is on fairly comfortable busses that only cost about a dollar per hour of travel. This means you can travel just about the entirety of the country for less than 50$. We found a bus for Riobamba, a stopping off town where we would be able to get a bus to Tena. The bus ride itself was fairly typical of the overall bus experience in South America. I sat next to an oversized lady that made it her priority to overflow and slowly commandeer more of my seat as time went on. Every time the bus stopped, food hawkers jump on trying to sell you every manner of snack food and meat sticks you can imagine. However, where this bus ride differed was the scenery. Guayaquil is extremely tropical and as you drive out of the city the landscape is peppered with banana trees. As you climb slowly higher into the mountains the banana trees disappear to simply be replaced by green. Green everywhere you look. It stretches forever. After the desert landscape of Peru, Ecuadorâs green is simply mind-numbing. Our bus arrived in Riobamba around 8pm. There are a couple terminals in the small mountain city and the busses to Tena were at a different one. We caught a cab to the Terminal Oriental (Jungle Terminal), the two bus companies were closed and there were no more busses for the night. In addition, the city block had lost all power, so it was pitch black minus the lights from candles and cars. The taxi driver recommended we go to another area to get a hotel. We quickly agreed and drove to another area that did have electricity and found ourselves a place to stay. Having not really had a chance to eat, we went in search of food. We walked around for about 5 minutes until we found a street full of street vendors. These vendors sell food right out of a small shack, but still have tables and seats to sit on. We were able to eat a delicious meal for less than 5$, combined. Not only delicious, but economical! We topped off our meal with gelato. After food, we returned to the hotel and called it a day.

item.title: Dec 14 - Into the Amazon
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Down the rabbit hole

Liz and I were up early in the morning such that we could catch an early morning bus to Tena. We were on the bus and out the terminal by 7am. The bus ride itself was mostly uneventful, but the scenery was once again beautiful. As we slowly descended into the Jungle, or the Oriente or Selva as the Ecuadorians call it, the surrounding green became even more permeating. Just to give perspective, about half of the country is Amazon rainforest, but most of the forest is inaccessible. There are still undiscovered tribes that live in the deeper parts of the forest. And in case you are wondering, they donât want to be discovered, because they kill anyone that stumbles upon them. If you would like more information, I highly watching Survivor Manâs episode on the Amazon rainforest (he goes to Ecuador for it) and almost gets eaten by a Jaguar. A little before lunchtime we pulled into Tena where we were greeted with a blast of humidity. I immediately began to sweat and within about 5 minutes my shirt was soaked. It did not help that I had to carry my backpack to the hostel, about 1km away. I should elaborate on the reason we chose to come to Tena. It is renowned for world class rafting. It is surrounded by a smattering of rivers of varying difficulty which allow any adventurer the level of difficulty they desire. After getting a place to stay, a place called âA Welcome Breakâ, which was quite clean and very cheap, we meandered around the town. The town itself is quite small and can be walked very fast, which made the overall meandering quite short. We did however investigate rafting companies and jungle tours. We arranged a rafting tour with a company called River People. They were not the cheapest, but they were the most talked about. In addition, when choosing to do something like rafting, I am not against paying a bit more to ensure my safety. For instance, our hostal was offering rafting trips for about 25$ less, but his raft looked like something I would buy at Walmart. We booked a Class IV river called the Jondachi-Hollin (pronounced Hondachi-Hoyin). After booking the rafting, we scoured the town (all few blocks) for a good deal on jungle tours. Unfortunately, to get the full force of the Amazon, one has to venture about 8 hours by bus to a place called Limoncocha. Since Liz and I did not have sufficient time for that, we opted for a one-day tour that would introduce us to the plants and basics of the jungle. (Iâll put in a quick review on the tour in the Dec 16 post). When we had finished arranging everything, we decided that we needed to go for a swim in the river that ran through town, but wanted to see the zoo first. According to the guide book, there was supposed to be an animal sanctuary in the middle of the river. However, we could not find the bridge that was supposed to be link the island to the bank of the river. Since the water was only about 50ft across and about knee-deep, we simply waded across to the island. Once we scrambled up the banks, we were greeted by a very weird sight. Instead of there being an animal sanctuary, it was only a small smattering of animals walking around freely, with some in cages. We were quite confounded, since it was supposed to be a very well-established mini-zoo. Rather there were monkeys swinging through the trees, a ant-eater like animal walking around, and a few other animals in cages. The most interesting animal though was a monkey, called Daniel, in a cage. When you got close, he would reach out his tail and his hand through the bars to touch you. His tail was extremely strong and could curl forcibly around your finger. It turns out that Daniel had gotten too aggressive and had to be put in the cage to protect people and the other animals. After walking around the small island, and seeing that most things were overgrown and unkempt, we were very confused as to why the guide book had talked about the place with such gusto. We found out from some other people at the hostal that there had been a flood in April of that year which had essentially wiped out most of the animals. The remaining ones were simply the survivors. This also explained the lack of a bridge, because that had been washed away. After our "animal safari", Liz and I walked to the swimming part of the river and spent a good amount of time cooling off. The cool water was a welcome respite after all the humidity. When we thought we were sufficiently cool, we returned to the hostal, changed into dry clothes, and went out to find dinner. As for dinner we decided to make food, if only so that we could eat vegetables. Despite the street meat (my term for the vendors) being delicious, they donât serve vegetables. So while it would be cheaper to eat out, we opted to cook so that we could eat some veggies. After dinner we chatted with some of the other people at the hostal and called in an early night in anticipation of rafting the next day.

item.title: Dec 15 - Rafting in Ecuador
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Rafting Company

Jondachi-Hollin

Today Liz and I were up earlyish and at the rafting place by 830am. The four other guys we would be sharing the day with showed up. They were a happy group made up of 3 people from LA and 1 from the Galapagos, all family. Soon after our guide and safety kayaker showed up and we were all piling in the van for the 25 minute drive to the river. The van could only drop us off close to the river though, and after that we had to walk about 30 minutes down a muddy (emphasis on muddy) track to get to the put-in point.

Bridge over the put-in point

Before the madness

Safety gear to be worn at all times

Once at the river, which due to rain the night before was running fast and big, we got our safety talk. After the talk we clambered into the raft and were off. The first part of the day (until lunch) was spent on mostly class III rapids, which while not large were continuous and great fun. The rain had made the level just perfect, not too fast and big, but not too slow and small. The river itself runs through a canyon for the first part of the morning. The scenery is amazing. The green-covered walls stretch up high above you, with butterflies, birds, and other animals swirling about you.

By lunchtime, everyone was starving, and we ended up eating all the food that had been brought along for lunch. This even included chocolate cake. After lunch came the class IV rapids. This meant bigger waves and faster water. It was awesome! We had the chance to ride on the front of the raft like cowboys. We were able to jump off and float through a few rapids. We stopped at some waterfalls and were able to jump off a cliff into the water. All in all, a great section of river.

Lunchtime

Unfortunately, all good things must come to an end, and so did our day of rafting. The ride back saw most of us pass out from all the adrenaline we had had during the day. Once back in town, we said our goodbyes and headed off our separate ways. Liz and I topped our the day with a healthy-serving of street meat from the vendors.

item.title: Dec 16 - Tour of the Amazon
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Amazon Jungle as seen from the top of a tree

Today was our jungle tour. Liz and I were at the office at 7am, but had to wait until 720am for the people to actually show up (even though they had said 7). After getting our rubber boots, we shuffled into a guyâs truck and began the 30 minute drive out to their reserve. We were dropped off at some buildings close off the road where we were given tea, while the guy chauffeuring us had breakfast. Up until this point, we thought this guy, Fausto was our guide. So when we began walking back into the forest on a paved concrete walkway, and he wasnât saying anything or explaining anything, we began to get a bit suspicious. After about 20 minutes we arrived at a cabana where we were introduced to our real guide. It turns out Fausto was merely dropping us off. We took in the sight of the forest and waited while the two guys got things in order. Fausto then explained that we would do a 3 hour walk with our guide, then we would eat lunch, rest a bit, and return to the road where we could catch a bus back to Tena. He informed us that we would have to pay for the bus, which was only 50 cents. At this point, I told Fausto that he was mistaken. The tour was all-inclusive, especially transportation. The fact he wanted to put us on a bus already pissed me off, but that he wanted us to pay was unacceptable. He said that he had paid for the truck to come out there. I told him that didnât matter, he was supposed to do that and that he would also pay for the bus back to town. By now Fausto, had in my mind, become a weasel. So of course he tried to play his comment off by saying that we had talked with the girl in the office and he couldnât know what she said, but that he would honor what she had promised. I told him good, glad he understood that. After Faustoâs little theatrics we started our jungle tour. The path led off into the shrubbery where we were soon engulfed by heat, humidy, green, trees, and insects. Our guide explained the different use of the plants, different types of trees, the medicinal plants, the most common insects, pointed out large spiders and some birds, and topped things off by letting us climb up a 60 meter tree to see the jungle from above the canopy. The rickety rebar ladder was not that comforting, but the view was spectacular. As far as the eye could see, trees and green pervaded the vision. After the tree, we returned to the cabana for lunch.

Into the bush

Local Resident

Ground Cover

Dragon's Blood - Anti-itch medicinal tree sap

Queen of the Jungle

Rickety Ladder + High Tree = Good view

After lunch we walked back along the concrete path to road and caught the bus back to Tena. The bus was a local bus, hence packed with people and bad music. It brought back memories of the busses in Peru for me. Once back in town, we returned to the hostal to shower off. The jungle had been brutally humid, and as such, had meant we had sweated almost non-stop. While the jungle tour had been interesting, it had also been a bit disappointing. This had nothing to do with the plants and insects we saw, but more to do with the company. Like most things, what they had said and what they had done, had been two different things. Fausto had been disingenuous and lied, and only when I confronted him and told him to his face what he would do, did he do it. For this reason, I do not recommend their company, MundoPuma. They were unprofessional and untrustworthy, and for this reason I recommend searching for another company.

item.title: Dec 17 - On to Quito
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
Liz and I were up early and on a bus by 630am to head to Quito. Before we had got on the bus though, I had bought some rice pudding (at least it is kind of like that with larger rice kernels) from a guy rolling it around on his cart. I had listened to another person try to buy some and had gotten the price before I approached. When I asked him how much it was, he quoted me a price 20 cents higher. I promptly said he was wrong and the other lady had just paid 50 cents. Caught in his lie, he just smiled and said âOk, no problemsâ and I replied âThatâs right, no problemsâ. I include this small story more as an example for how vendors (be them street or in a store), continually try to hike prices on me (or other westerners). While I know that I could fully pay the extra 20 cents, and it wouldnât make that much difference, it is the principle of the matter. I am just lucky I can speak Spanish to recognize when they are trying to rip me off.
The bus ride itself was mostly passed in a sleepy stupor as Liz and I dozed for most of the 5 hours. We periodically awoke, took in the beautiful sight of the surrounding greenery, then fell back asleep. Once in Quito, the capital of Ecuador and a bustling metropolis, we decided to give the public transportation a try. Since using the Trolle (a bus with its own lane) costs only 25 cents, while a taxi would have been 10 dollars or up, it was a fairly easy decision. The bus itself was in great condition and getting to the part of town we needed to be in proved to be quick and painless. From the terminal we walked to our hostal, stopping along the way for lunch.
After checking in to the hostal, we had decided we wanted to venture to a museum about 10 blocks away. However, after about 2 blocks, we were met with a huge and heavy downpour. We ducked into a cafÃ© to try and dry off and wait out the rain. Well, we waited, and waited, and the rain did not stop. So instead of trying to slog it down to the museum, we simply returned to the hostal to change into dry clothes and get warm. Since the heavy downpour did not abate all afternoon, and we did not have any more clothes to spare, we stayed at the hostal to watch some movies and stay warm in bed. We only got out at one point to make dinner, but then quickly retreated back to the warmth of the blankets. While we didnât get to see too much of Quito, we did catch up on some movies. We only hoped that the next day would see a stop to the rain and allow us to venture out a bit easier.

item.title: Part 1: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 1 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions.

Background

A quick explanation: OLPC or One Laptop Per Child is a non-profit organization started out of MIT and run out of Cambridge. They built a unique laptop that is low in cost and runs off a derivative of Linux. This laptop is aimed for children in developing countries to help provide them cheap education and a way to connect with the greater world. Last fall semester while I was still a student at UC Berkeley, we were visited by a group of people from OLPC. They described their program in detail. They also mentioned a new contingent of the company that was funding interns to work in deployment countries. I had a friend there that had coincidentally done this the summer prior (â09) and had described the experience as âawesomeâ. Thinking this was a chance to travel and provide community-service, I jumped at the chance. Fast forward to April, when all the interns were notified of their selection. We were given two time options, a two-month period over the summer months or three months in the fall. I choose to do the fall section, allowing myself time to work over the summer and prepare for my time in Peru. Soon enough the end of summer had arrived and I was on my way.

What I got myself into

I had hoped that the interns over the summer would have been able to provide some context for the situation we might encounter. All I really knew was how to use the laptop and that they had worked in a town called Huaraz. One of the previous interns had kept a blog, but it was brief. It focused more Spainâs prospects in the world cup rather than the actual work being done. Over a period of 1.5 months, it only had 13 posts. Another intern kept a blog that I was able to find in the last week of our time in Peru, but it too had little information on the actual work being done. It focused more on her lifestyle and less on the work being done. Therefore, I had almost no idea of the actual work the interns were doing. We were assured that we would have all questions answered by the Ministry once in Peru. Essentially, the other interns Hope and Josh, and myself knew almost nothing about what we were getting ourselves into, but were excited for the opportunity. Please come back tomorrow for the next part of the series. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6

item.title: Part 2: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 2 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions. The interns over the summer had been subject to a week of training at the ministry of education in preparation for their jobs. We had been provided âtrainingâ over the summer by our volunteer supervisor. These trainings had consisted of long periods of time talking about laptop basics (i.e. taking a picture, pasting it into the write activity) via internet chat. Apparently, the interns over the summer had been much less technical savvy, and he was under impression that the fall group was the same. This was not the case. Two of us are engineers and the other a very savvy philosophy major. Over the summer there had been two engineers and ten teaching interns. The type of training we required was quite different. We probably would have been better served by discussing the teaching being done in the classes. At no point was the actual lesson plans being used in the class rooms discussed. Rather we discussed abstract concepts like the purpose of the laptop (a tool to help kids learn). While knowing the basics of the laptop functions is nice, it would have been preferable to learn ways to implement the laptops in the classroom.

Helping the students

Due to our âtrainingâ over the summer, we were to only have one day of training at the ministry. Therefore upon our arrival at the ministry, we assumed that we would be trained in how to implement the laptops with the class. However, for the whole first half of the day we spent the time with two different ladies. They continually talked about how our job was to convince the teachers to use the laptops. We were to be creative in figuring out ways to make the teachers utilize the laptops, because as we were told many did not want to. The other topic they discussed was how proud they were of their indigenous population. While this is a noble topic, it had almost no bearing on teaching with the laptop. The only teaching parts we discussed were how to make books in eToys and how to connect to each otherâs laptops using the mesh network. The major positive part of our training was we were given a copy of the Peru software image, which is needed to flash the machines. Apparently flashing the machines is the only method of fixing any problems related to the software and any hardware problems should just be reported. Along with this software image we were also shown how to change the name and colors of the little XO person for the laptops. While you would think this should be easy, it is not. Rather one has to open up the terminal activity and manually enter a series of English commands. Not only is use of the terminal out of any teacherâs technical grasp, but so is English commands, even ones that are copied.

Concept Maps

To avoid having laptops stolen, each laptop is activated using a key that lasts for the duration of the year. This key is included in the software image and part of the flashing process. While in theory this key should kick in and work fine, the laptopsâ internal clocks often get out of sync. This means the laptop thinks it is Feb 2008 or some other random date, rather than the current date. This causes the laptop to shut down and no longer allow functioning, rendering the machine useless. Essentially the key points of our jobs would be to convince teachers to use the laptops and to be glorified laptop software flashers. When OLPC originally described this job, I was supposed to be installing Servers and SatLinks to provide Internet to schools, fixing software bugs, or replacing broken hardware parts. It was turning out that my job was going to be much different than originally promised. item.title: Part 3: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 3 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions. Our bus trip to Huaraz, which was long and somewhat uneventful, can be revisited at this post. The next day we met with the Ancash laptop specialist, who would be directing us where to go for our time in Huaraz. He informed Hope and Josh they would be spending two weeks at a time in one school, while I would be traveling to many schools and working for two days at time. At this point he handed us handwritten maps with approximate walking times and travel times between schools. The numbers at first were staggering and as I would come to find out, the reality, even more so.

Ancash Specialist

As I began to visit schools, I slowly became more familiar with the laptop and its limitations. Most of the workshops the Ministry had suggested I discarded because they were cumbersome and unrealistic. The reality of most schools was they only had a basic knowledge of how to operate the laptops. Additionally, the mouse pads, besides having a terrible design, often became so dirty that they stopped functioning. The most disturbing fact we discovered though was the software image being used was over two years old. While this doesnât necessarily have to be a cause of problems, it is when the software never gets updated and bugs never get fixed.

Concentration

Peru had designed its own software image of Sugar, the XO operating system. A good way to think of Sugar and the image would be like a horse and donkey. They are somewhat similar but still different enough that they are separate animals. When Peru created their own software image they essentially cut themselves off from all the assistance provided to updating Sugar out of Sugar Labs. What this really means is the continual bug updates and other fixes being pushed to the normal Sugar image from the labs (think windowâs updates or mac software updates), would never reach the Peru image, until the updates had been customized for the Peru image. This creates a huge time-lag and bottleneck. A majority of the programs have some serious issues that have not been fixed since their initial deployment. No follow-up is performed to solve problems. What is worse, is that many students and teachers cannot understand when problems occur and why they are occurring. They only understand that something is not working and get extremely frustrated. This usually causes them to abandon using the programs and also lose confidence in the laptop. To give one an idea of the severity of the issues, it took Hope, Josh, and me the course of a few months to discover a variety of errors and minor solutions to get the programs to function as intended.

item.title: Part 4: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 4 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions.

Software is Only Half the Problem

While a myriad of software issues plague the laptop, they are accompanied by some equally problematic hardware issues. The first and most problematic problem is the touchpad. For some laptops, the touchpad simply does not function correctly. While trying to move the pointer around, the pointer will jump from one side of the screen to the other, without rhyme or reason. The children will often yell the words âNo sirveâ or âSe correâ in frustration. Translated it means, âIt doesnât workâ and âItâs (the pointer) running aroundâ. The touchpad problem is exacerbated by the fact that the children rarely bathe and have extremely dirty hands. This causes the touchpads to become very dirty and work even less. One can provide a soft reset of the touchpad using a series of combinations on the keyboard, but it rarely fixes the problem.

Click the mouse!

The keyboards are also a big problem. They are built with rubber and are of cheap quality. Therefore, the kids quickly rip keys and have to replace them with tape and draw the letter in. In addition, actually trying to convey the idea of modifier keys beyond the use of shift and the accent mark, is almost impossible. If you show them one letter and explain that this works for all keys on the keyboard, they will not understand. Some might say this is my fault for not being able to teach them, but really it is more than that. Showing the kids one idea and trying to explain how to extrapolate this to other ideas, just doesnât work. Itâs just not how the kids are taught to learn. They are not encouraged to think outside the box (a phrase which translates but holds no meaning) and problem solve. The teaching method used by the teachers is call and response or copying things from the board. Kids do not work in groups or independently to exercise critical thinking, but rather will only repeat or copy what is given to them by the teacher. item.title: Part 5: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 5 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions.

Who needs training? Just put the laptops out there and amazing things will happen.

After about a month and a half, we had pretty much found all the software problems and come to grips with the hardware ones. However, one problem still remained: the issue of teacher training. Peruvian teachers break down into two groups, those trying to get accredited and accepted as full-time teachers, they work on contracts that last a couple years, and those that are accredited and pretty much set with a job for as long as they want. Those who are contracted tend to be younger and more accepting of technology. The other ones tend to be older, 45 years plus, and have almost no experience with technology.

Younger Teacher

The younger ones tend to catch on very fast and grasp the concepts quite fast. Even if they did not know where to start, once shown they caught on fast. They were also incentivized to do better, because they wanted to get hired permanently. The unfortunate part is that these teachers really only make up about 10% of the teachers I encountered. The other group, the older ones, tended to be much more difficult to teach. Disregarding their lack of experience with technology, they also simply did not have basic training in certain topics. This consisted of not knowing basic geometry, mathematics, or other topics. The technology issue was simply compounded by the inadequate education. The main idea here is that if the teachers were going to be able to use these laptops, they needed some serious training. The sad part is that there are tons of resources online, but most teachers do not know how to use the internet to access them. Most teachers do not even have email addresses, let alone the ability to search through google to find ideas on how to utilize the laptops. Internet access itself was non-existent in the villages, but they did have access to it in Huaraz. The opportunity was there, but the knowledge of how to take advantage of it was not.

Thinking Hard

Around this point, an article came out describing some of the issues with the Peruvian OLPC deployment (read the article). In it many issues are discussed, but beyond the issues, it is the response by Oscar Barreto that is disconcerting. He replies in the comments over 15 times, trying to discredit the article and draw attention to how the program is working. In fact, in his responses, he sadly only confirms one thing: the ministry has no idea how to make the program work. My favorite response was that if you just put the laptops out there in schools, and allow kids to play with them, then they will learn to utilize the machines and great things will happen (I cannot document this comment because it appears to have been deleted, but I guarantee it existed.). Based on my experience, this is completely wrong. The only thing that happens is the laptops get opened, turned on, kids and teachers get frustrated by hardware and software bugs, donât understand what to do, and promptly box them up to put back in the corner. **Nicholas Negroponte, the head CEO of OLPC, claims the same thing in this article**

She's not impressed

It appears that Mr. Barreto has not used the laptops, because when he claims âAre you purposefully ignoring the laptops come loaded with hundreds of reading texts, a 30,000 entries Spanish Wikipedia and several other things that just by themselves mean a quantum leap compared to what teachers and students had available before?â, it belies a simple knowledge about the machine. The Peru image has almost no books and any books on the machine have to be accessed via the browser activity. While Wikipedia is a great resource for information, it is not a book. The âbooksâ are simply pages of html text. Html text will never engage a child like a book does. The ministryâs response to the article simply drew attention to one important fact: they did not want to hear criticism, even if it was constructive. They only wanted to hear that things were going great. To me, this really only said one thing: They did not care about the kids learning, but only about appearing to be doing something for the indigenous people. If people asked the administration, what are you doing to help the native people, they can say how theyâve given them laptops. They donât have to say that they donât train the teachers and that the laptops donât get used by the kids. The problem with the ministry is compounded by politics as well. Since the program was inherited from a prior administration, and when administrations change so do all the people in the agencies, nobody had a good idea of what they should be doing. This problem will repeat with the next change of administration. Rather, the current administration expanded the program without addressing the issues. More or less, they did this to garner more votes for the next election by allowing them to say theyâre supporting education. Instead of doing the hard thing of providing training and follow-up, they just put laptops out in the field, and disappear. They cite geography more than anything else, as the barrier that keeps them from following up. Well, after having spent time walking between schools, I understand the issue of geography, but it is not insurmountable. In fact, a person equipped with a truck could access almost all the schools.

Teacher becomes the student

After this series of events, one thing was for sure, the teachers were not going to get the help they needed from the ministry. The ministry was only good for lip service. They were in Lima, talking about the things that were happening, rather than in the field making it happen. As a friend of mine said, they were busy practicing âmental masturbationâ. item.title: Part 6: Whoâs to blame? Why the OLPC plan in Peru is failing and who is causing it.
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
This is part 6 of a 6 part series that critically examines my experience in Peru and the situation I encountered. Part 1 |Â Part 2 |Â Part 3 |Â Part 4 |Â Part 5 |Â Part 6 Note: I am a graduated engineer that has been taught to think through problems and search for solutions. I am not an expert on Peru and I do not pretend to be. I am drawing on my own experiences and interpretations. My observations span twenty schools and countless interactions with the ministry and teachers over a period of approximately three months. In addition, I often refer to Hope and Josh, but I do not speak for their opinions.

So, what is the problem and how can we fix it?

After all this I hope that it has become clear, that there isnât just one problem, but a series of problems. OLPC built a laptop that doesnât work well and has many problems. The Peruvian ministry of education has software that is too buggy and an infrastructure not built to support the deployment. Teachers do not have the training and sadly, the ability to change their situation. So how do you make the deployment work with what is already there?

Dios Mio!

First, fix the software and hardware bugs. The good news is that this is being undertaken by a couple of people in the ministry. The bad news is that even with this update, it will still be years behind the current Sugar release available from the Sugar labs. Deployment and update on the old machines will also be extremely hard, despite the ministryâs assertion that it will be done by next march (they themselves say geography is an issue). Hardware-wise any schools that get new laptops will have machines that have much better functioning mouse pads, but any schools with the original machines, will still suffer from the hardware problems. Second, train the teachers and follow-up. Many of the teachers could grasp the concepts and how to use the machines, if only provided with the right training. This means, one-on-one training in their school where they are comfortable and relaxed. Calling all the teachers to Huaraz for a big workshop for one day, accomplishes almost nothing. The teachers do not learn well in groups, but need help one-by-one. We saw both systems tried, and without a doubt workshops do not work, but one-on-one instruction does. Equally important is follow-up. Going back to the teachers, asking them about the problems theyâre having, and working towards solutions. The teachers are the people working with the laptops day-in and day-out, they know what needs to change and be fixed. Third, stop making excuses and do the hard work. People sitting in Lima talking about the problems that stand in the way, like geography, will not help anybody. Building a system that can train and support the deployment takes people in the field, and that is where the ministry should be deploying resources. The sad thing is that while that will help the children, it wonât change the politic picture. Putting people out in the country-side, wonât get more votes, so it wonât happen. So who is to blame through all this?

Why don't you tell me?

The truth is that almost everybody is to blame. Everybody has messed up on some level. OLPC, the ministry, the interns, everyone has in some way made mistakes that have created a deployment that doesnât accomplish its fundamental goal, helping kids change their lives for the better. Does this mean that there arenât success stories? No, there are success stories, but they are few and the reality is not the success stories. And it is irresponsible and naÃ¯ve to tout a few stories as proof that the program is working. After this whole article, I donât want you to think that I am only complaining. What I am trying to do is bring attention to the issues and problems that face the program, to realistically open the eyes of the public to what the situation is like on the ground. I hope that after this, the program can be approached more realistically. Honestly, what I really want is to see the kids have the ability to change their situations using machines like the laptops. I think most people do. But, acknowledging the reality of the situation and then figuring out how to make things works is much better than just making excuses and not really fixing the problem.

Who?

item.title: Mountain Biking in the East Bay
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
There are some serious hills in the San Francisco East Bay area. What this means for bikers is some great trails. After having searched for a while, I found the information regarding the two parks closest to me a bit lacking, and decided that I'd like to do a write-up to help provide some better information. The two parks I will talk about here are Joaquin Miller park and Redwood Regional. They are only separated by Skyline (the road).

Joaquin Miller

Joaquin Miller is a great little park maintained by the city of Oakland. It has a multitude of trails from single-track to the wider walking trails. It offers a great amount of variety for difficulty and fun. The best part about the park is it is right off of Highway 13 in Oakland. A good trail: Parking can be found at multiple places around the park, however if you are looking to get right into the biking portion, I recommend Castle Dr. X Holyrood Dr. From there, take the trail going off to the left (not the one down the hill). Stay on this trail until you come to a small option to go off to the right, it will be right after the Bayview trail will go off to the left. After only a few moments you will get to the cinderella trail on your right. This is by far the best single track in the park. Go down cinderella! It is full of jumps, twists, and turns. From there you have two options for riding back up the hill - left at the bottom: circling back around on the Sunset Trail to the Sequoia Bayview Trail and ride that all the way up, veer left at the top of it; right at the bottom - Sunset Trail back to Castle Drive and up to castle drive until the road starts to bend left, there will be a super steep driveway, go up that and then on the right is Westview Trail, take that up to the top and then ride along the road for about 200ft and you'll be back at your start. There are other trails in the park that can be explored as well, but many are off-limits to bicyclists. As always, be very friendly to pedestrians. Learn more on their official website or download a Trail Map

Redwood Regional

Redwood Regional is much larger than Joaquin Miller and boasts many more options. The only trails where bicyclists are permitted are the ones that ring the park. These are the West and East ridge trails. There are multiple signs posted that threaten severe fines for mountain bikers that veer from those paths. The overall loop is probably about 8 hours. At the south end of the loop you drop down into the valley which is a great ride, whichever side you go down, but the ride up is definitely a butt-kicker. Make sure you have enough water, because it can get pretty warm there during the day. Learn more on their official website or download a Trail Map For more information on east bay mountain biking trails, check out the Bicycle Trails Council of the East Bay.

item.title: ZipList - A grocery management system
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: Recently I had to figure out a solution to deal with groceries. I have a few roommates and coordinating the grocery shopping can get a little hectic. Making sure two people don't buy the same things or that nobody gets things, can be a big problem! Trust me, hungry people are not happy people :) So, after hearing the "we SHOULD figure out a better way to do things," I mentioned that we could probably find an application that would allow us to use our phones to solve our grocery woes. I searched around a bit and found a great post on life hacker (view post) about an application called ZipList. Luckily Ziplist proved to be the perfect solution. Ziplist allows us to use our smartphones (Android and iPhone) to keep a common grocery list synced among four people. In addition, its got a recipe feature that allows you to add a recipe to your account and then automatically import those ingredients into the grocery list. They have another feature that is pretty cool, although not too well implemented yet, that allows you to add the stores that you normally visit and organize the store aisles. What this means is you can have your list automatically lay itself out according to aisle to streamline what you pickup and where. The only problem is you have to do the layout by hand the first time, which is somewhat of a pain. Ziplist has a website and apps for Android and iPhone which makes it a near-perfect fit for grocery shopping.

item.title: Dropbox and using it as an automatic version history
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded: First off, sorry for the lack of posts. I plan on trying to get back into a more regular flow. It has been difficult because I've been searching for a job (more info on that in later posts) and focusing on doing CODING PROBLEMS. Anyways, I first off apologize for the lack of posts and hope to make it up with something useful here. While many people use Dropbox, there are still a lot who don't, and sadly, a lot of people who don't realize how useful it can be. I should explain that Dropbox is a free online storage company that allows you to have a built-in folder to your computer that automatically syncs to the cloud and any other computer you have Dropbox installed on (literally drag-n-drop functionality). My main reason for this post is to describe the version history feature that can be an absolute life saver. Version history, in its most simplest terms, is a way to keep track of something as you change it. So say you have a word document, everytime you save it, you overwrite the previous state, but with a version history, you will actually be saving a new state. What do this really mean? Let's say you mess something up, or just want to go back to a prior version of a document, getting there could be a real pain (how many times can I press undo...). However, this is where Dropbox steps in. By having a document saved in your Dropbox folder, every time you save it, it actually gets reuploaded as a new version. Translation - AUTOMATIC File BACKUP. That is an amazing feature. Lets break that down into sections. AUTOMATIC - You don't have to think about it. This is a great thing. BACKUP - You have a copy forever accessible on the Dropbox website. This is a amazing thing. (Ever have a hard drive die? Life saver!) So now instead of manually saving a file as File1 or File2 to determine versions, simply save it and you'll have a dated history snapshot of the file. And that my friends is amazing. If Dropbox sounds like something you'd like to use, simply click this link - http://db.tt/NvekR2h - and sign-up. You'll help me out by giving me a bit more space (everytime you refer someone, you get more space) and you'll help yourself by not losing files anymore.

item.title: Travel Resources
item.dc:creator: jpatzer
item.content:encoded:
I ran into an old friend yesterday and as all post-college kids are prone to do, we started talking about what we are "doing with our lives". The sentence is probably the most feared and difficult one to answer. While I personally don't ever think that it is fully answered, you can at least figure out parts. Anyways, I digress. While I was in Peru with OLPC I got to meet a lot of travelers and learn about a lot of resources available. It really made me appreciate how much travel can make you grow and learn as a person. All the new experiences and interactions are on the whole positive and useful. Well, I got to talking with this friend and started to describe the traveling experience, and really saw him get excited. See, he is currently living at home with his parents, and while not a bad situation, definitely one he wants to change. When he said I just want to move out and have a little money saved, I recommend that he take that money and buy a plane ticket, and go. It was one of those statements where you see someone just totally absorb an idea and really consider it on the spot. One of the "I never thought of that, but it sounds really doable." It was awesome. Since I gathered together such a nice list of resources while in Peru, I told him I would them to him. But as I was writing the email, I thought, this would make an awesome blog post. So compiled below is a list of websites, blog posts, and other resources that can really be used to find cheap places to go, cheap plane tickets, cheap places to stay, and all other sorts of goodies. *** My last bit of advice is this: free advice is good, advice you pay for is better. Some of the sites might provide services that are minimal, but the potential advice that one can garner is going to be about 50X better than the free stuff they show. Just keep that in mind when deciding to pay. ** None of these sites asked me to do this. They are what I personally find useful. Keep that in mind.

Nomadic Matt's Travel Site

http://www.nomadicmatt.com/ --> Probably the best one for information. A must read. He has lots of links to other peoples site that might have more place specific information for you. (My friend Hope hates his writing style, but his content is great, so can't argue with that :P)

The Art of Non-conformity

http://chrisguillebeau.com/3x5/ --> A must read for anyone. Even if you aren't doing travel. His books and posts are absolutely inspiring. Want to break out of the mundane and do something with your life? Tangibly? This is your man to help show you how. **** His travel siteÂ http://travelhacking.org/ could literally save you hundreds of dollars with ideas on how to get cheap tickets and travel on the cheap. Well worth the price to pay to get his advice if you're new to the travel game.

Cheapest Destinations

http://travel.booklocker.com/ --> Great one for learning about places that are cheap to travel to, and cheap to travel and live in

How to use Couchsurfing to See the World

http://www.getrichslowly.org/blog/2009/08/03/how-to-use-couchsurfing-to-see-the-world/ --> A great post on how to leverage free lodging while traveling.

Matador Travel

http://matadortravel.com --> Great site for info and destination knowledge

Hostel Bookers

http://www.hostelbookers.com/ --> Great site for booking places to stay and kind of seeing what prices are like in a country

Blog Post -Â Travel full-time for less than $14,000 per year

http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/cheap-travel/ --> Inspiring post

Post on sites to use to book traveling

http://www.getrichslowly.org/blog/2009/12/01/5-little-known-websites-that-will-save-you-time-and-money-when-booking-airfare-online/ --> A couple different sites that you can use to leverage to get cheap tickets

TravelZoo

http://www.travelzoo.com/ --> Great site for finding cheap airfare and other goodies. I would recommend that once you know where you want to go, go to the store, read some of the guide books on the places, see which ones you like, and purchase one of them. No more than one, remember you'll have to carry that weight :)
